In a world in which corporate entities can be as influential as governments, Richard Neville is convinced that consumers will prefer to support brands that put good things in the world. His agency Animl works with Unilever’s Dirt Is Good brands to understand the changing nature of childhood in the 21st century.

Rania Bahaa is an Environmental Specialist at Unilever Mashreq in Egypt. Bahaa has led several innovative programs, across four Unilever factories, to meet the challenge that Unilever factories should create zero waste to landfill. This included the Waraqa Center, a program that created economic opportunities for local community members who re-craft food and packaging by-products into second lives as new products that they sell. The Waraqa Centre and communication around it is helping to shift the local and Egyptian community perspective on sustainability.
Lord Nicholas Stern studies the economics of climate change. He is a co-author of the position paper presented to the UN's 2014 Climate Summit, called "The New Climate Economy."

Andrew Winston is a globally recognized expert on how companies can navigate and profit from humanity’s biggest challenges. His views on strategy have been sought after by many of the world’s leading companies, including Boeing, HP, Kimberly-Clark, PepsiCo, and Unilever. Winston’s book The Big Pivot lays out a practical and optimistic roadmap for how companies can thrive in a hotter, scarcer, more open world.

In addition to her position as Global Customer Service Manager, Viviana Alvarez is a Unilever Global Foundation Ambassador and the President and co-founder of an NGO called Help to Haiti (H2H). In 2010, she was driven to help the people of Haiti after the devastating earthquake that struck. H2H remains focused on delivering basic needs, infrastructure, education, health and micro-financing to Haitian families.

Mark Jackson is CEO of Jackson Farms LS, Inc and currently serves as a National Director of the American Soybean Association. He is a fifth generation Iowa farmer who practices sustainable production and environmental responsibility in his modern family farming operations. He was one of the original farmers who pioneered sustainable soybean farming with Unilever.

Einav is the lead Corporate Chef at Unilever’s North America’s kitchens. Her role is to bring culinary insights to both products and recipes as well as help the American home cook put a tasty meal on the table. She uses her Chef’s hat to lend credibility to products that can be an easy solution to creating home cooked meals and building sustainable culinary solution to the question “What’s for dinner tonight”? Gefen graduated and taught at the Institute of Culinary Education in NYC.

Introducing “the man that buys the most food in America,” Jack Sinclair is the executive vice president of the Walmart US Grocery Division and is responsible for all aspects of the merchandise grocery business at Walmart’s stores in the US. Sinclair joined Walmart in 2007 from McCurrach, a U.K.-based field merchandising business. He has also previously worked for Tesco and Safeway PLC, where he eventually served on the board of directors that led the merger of Safeway PLC and Morrisons.

By building on the Greyston Bakery’s thirty-year heritage as a model for social enterprise using entrepreneurship to address the issues of generational poverty, President and CEO Mike Brady serves Yonkers, NY as a force for personal transformation and community economic renewal. Greyston is best known for a 24- year relationship of baking brownies for Ben and Jerry’s ice cream. Mike’s passion for social entrepreneurism and the use of business to solve social issues are fundamental to his work at Greyston Bakery.
Mac Barnett is a bestselling author of books for children.
Rosie King challenges stereotypes of people with autism and contextualizes the issue by asking us, “Why be normal?”
American journalist and Havana resident Gail Reed spotlights a Cuban medical school that trains doctors from low-income countries who pledge to serve communities like their own.
B. N. Horowitz, MD is a cardiologist and visiting professor at Harvard University's department of human evolutionary biology who turns to the natural world for insights into human well being.
At the Center for Disease Dynamics, Economics & Policy, economist Ramanan Laxminarayan looks at big-picture issues of global health.
Dr. Leana Wen is Baltimore City's Health Commissioner.
Antonio Donato Nobre researches the “ingenious systems” of the Amazon. His work illustrates the beautiful complexity of this region, as well as its fragility against a backdrop of climate change.
Debra Jarvis isn't your typical hospital chaplain. With wry wit, she aims to comfort patients -- and also challenge them.
Marc Abrahams writes about research that makes people laugh, and then think.

Bryan Kramer is a social business strategist and the CEO of PureMatter, where he’s led his agency to consistent growth over the last 10 years, earning a spot as one of Silicon Valley’s fastest-growing private companiesby the Silicon Valley Business Journal. He is the author of the bestselling book "Human to Human: #H2H." He has extensive experience in brand marketing with a focus on integrated communications and strategic business planning.

Inhi Cho Suh is the Vice President of Big Data Integration and Governance for IBM Software Group. She is a thought leader in the information management, big data and analytics marketplace. Inhi is responsible for the product portfolio and business direction of the division which is comprised of data management, information governance, information integration, master data management, data security, data privacy and emerging capabilities such as hadoop, stream computing and context computing.

Gianluca Ambrosetti is the Head of Research for Airlight Energy, a Swiss-based supplier of innovative technology for the large- scale production of electricity using solar power and for energy storage. He holds a PhD in physics/nanotechnology from the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Lausanne (EPFL) and an MSc in theoretical physics from the University of Bologna. In his free time he plays professional saxophone following in the footsteps of his famous jazz musician father.

Monika Blaumueller is a consultant at IBM, focusing on integrated solutions to transform healthcare delivery. Her Distributed Curriculum Model for restructuring healthcare education was endorsed by the National Institutes of Health and the Department of Health and Human Services and was sent by the State Department to 57 international posts. She was also named an honorary member of the University of Pittsburgh Medical Supercourse Faculty for her contributions to the continuing education of healthcare practitioners in Africa and Asia.

Kareem Yusuf is responsible for software development and SaaS operations for the ExperienceOne customer engagement solution set in IBM, a core element of IBM’s Smarter Commerce initiative. He has been with IBM for 16 years, joining IBM’s software development lab in Hursley, U.K. after completing a PhD from the University of Leeds. Outside his day to day duties, Yusuf maintains an active interest in all things technical, with a particular interest in digital media and programming languages.
A columnist for Forbes, Kare Anderson writes on behavioral research-based ways to become more deeply connected.

Charlene is CEO and Principal Analyst at Altimeter Group, and author of the New York Times bestseller "Open Leadership." She is also the coauthor of the bestselling book "Groundswell." She is one of the foremost experts on social media and a consultant and independent thought leader on leadership, strategy, social technologies, interactive media and marketing.

Mike Sempert is a songwriter/composer/producer best known as the band leader and singer for Birds & Batteries. After many years of making albums and touring the country with B&B, Mike took a break from the indie rock hustle to focus on other aspects of his life. He got a dog, moved to LA and married his longtime love. Inevitably, a bunch of songs came together, many of them centered around these changes and the questions creative people often face as they stare into the oblivion of adulthood.
Susan Etlinger promotes the smart, well-considered and ethical use of data.

Erick Brethenoux leads the strategy and vision for IBM Business Analytics. He leads the Customer Analytics, Decision Management and Analytics Inside initiatives across IBM software, hardware, services and research organizations. Brethenoux has published extensively in the domains of artificial intelligence systems, system sciences, applied mathematics, complex systems and cybernetics. He has held various academic positions at the University of Delaware and the Polytechnic School of Africa in Gabon.

Marie Wallace is currently an analytics strategist for IBM, having spent more than a decade in the research and development division building content, semantic and social analytics technologies which today underpin such solutions as IBM Watson. In recent years her primary focus has been on the analysis of people networks to deliver smarter, personalized and contextualized solutions for individuals and organizations.

Florian Pinel is a Senior Software Engineer in the Watson Life department of the IBM Watson Group. He received an M.S. in Computer Science and Engineering from Ecole Centrale de Paris in France and a Culinary Arts diploma from the Institute of Culinary Education in New York. His current research interests are computational creativity and cognitive computing, and he is the lead architect of the Chef Watson project.

Lisa Seacat DeLuca is a mobile software engineer specializing in hybrid mobile development for IBM’s Open Technology and Cloud Performance organization. DeLuca is a self-published author of a children’s book, "A Robot Story," teaching kids how to count to ten in binary. In 2014, she was named one of Network World’s 50 Most Fascinating People in the World of Technology and is the first woman in IBM history to reach the 100th plateau achievement level, having filed more than 370 patent applications.

Francis de los Reyes works with cutting-edge microbiological techniques in environmental biotech. But his passion, both professionally and personally, is helping to improve the plight of the world’s 2.5 billion people living without adequate sanitation. Reyes is a TED Fellow.
Susan Colantuono is the CEO and founder of Leading Women.
Laura Boushnak is a Kuwaiti-born Palestinian photographer whose work focuses on women, literacy and education reform in the Arab world.
Dedicated to increasing awareness about Northern Indian Ocean blue whales, Asha de Vos is also committed to inspiring the next generation of marine biologists.
Boniface Mwangi is an award-winning Kenyan photographer, artist and activist. He is a TED Fellow.
Bassam Tariq delights in making eclectic career choices. A blogger, a filmmaker, and a butcher's shop owner, the common theme linking everything together is his boundless celebration of humanity.
Catherine Crump is an assistant clinical professor at Berkeley Law School who focuses on the laws around data and surveillance.
Patrícia Medici leads the longest running conservation project to protect the threatened lowland tapir.
Joe Landolina is a TED Fellow and the inventor of VETI-GEL.
An architect and urban designer, Alison Killing uses journalism, filmmaking and exhibitions to help people better understand the built environment.
Sangu Delle is an entrepreneur and clean water activist. A TED Fellow who hails from Ghana, he sees incredible potential in the African economy.
Anastasia Taylor-Lind is a documentary photographer who works around the world on issues relating to women, birth rights, depopulation and post-conflict regions.
The co-host of TEDxMidAtlantic, Dave Troy is a serial entrepreneur and a data-viz fan.
Jon Gosier is a serial tech entrepreneur and early-stage startup investor. In 2015, Time magazine listed him as one of the "12 New Faces of Black Leadership."
Angelo Vermeulen wears many hats, including one as a crew commander for NASA, another as an artist and community organizer.
Bel Pesce left Brazil to study at MIT. But after a successful stint in Silicon Valley, she returned to inspire others with great ideas in her country to make them a reality.
Jeff Iliff is a neuroscientist who explores the unique functions of the brain.

Karin Nilsdotter is Co-Founder and CEO of Space Travel Alliance and Managing Partner of Spaceport Sweden, two pioneering initiatives to realize the dream of commercial space travel. Karin founded TEDxKiruna and initiated Creative Space, a do-tank for young talent across science, arts and tourism.

Jay Cousins is an inventor and entrepreneur who has sold millions of products. He is a catalyst for cultural change, helping to establish makerspaces and events in Germany and Egypt. He creates opportunities for businesses, hackers, artists and geeks to understand each other and collaborate. His latest projects include the Betabook.

Stefan Gross-Selbeck is Partner at BCG Digital Ventures. He has 20 years of experience as an operator and a consultant in the digital industry. Stefan served as the Chief Executive Officer of XING AG for four years, driving the expansion of the XING network. From 2002 until 2007 he was an executive for eBay in roles including COO of the China operation and Managing Director of eBay Germany. He holds a PhD in Law and an MBA from INSEAD.

Carey Kolaja is Vice President of Global Product Solutions at PayPal. She has more than 20 years of diverse experience in financial services and technology consulting at companies such as UBS Warburg, Waterstone Consulting, Windomar Financial and divine interVentures. She earned a BS from the University of Indiana and is a graduate from the Executive Program at Stanford University.

Dario Gil is a leading technologist and executive at IBM Research. As Director of Symbiotic Cognitive Systems, he leads a strategy focused on the creation of learning systems that are designed to enhance and scale human expertise. He received his Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science from MIT.

Through her role in BCG’s Center for Sensing & Mining the Future, Alison Sander tracks megatrends to help clients find their next areas of growth. She earned an MBA from Harvard Business School, a JD from Harvard Law School and a BA in political science with high honors from the University of Chicago. Sander is a member of The Council on Foreign Relations, a Board member of the World Resources Institute, an Overseer of the Museum of Science and a founder of AltWheels.

Peter Kirn is an electronic musician and creative technologist. Classically trained as a pianist and composer, he now produces experimental/ambient music and live techno. He is known as a creative tech journalist and editor of Created Digital Music (CDM), which for ten years has been a hub for covering expressive technologies for music and visual performance. He is co-creator of the open source MeeBlip synthesizer hardware.
BCG's Rainer Strack advocates for companies to adopt a "people advantage" -- because employee-centered thinking can go a long way.

Alexander Tuerpitz is BCG’s Public Sector practice leader for the Middle East and has served as the Global Topic Leader for Labor Markets, Employment and Welfare. He is an expert on public policies, strategy, operations and IT and has worked across Europe, the US, Asia and the Middle East. He has served as a member of the World Economic Forum's Global Agenda Council on gender parity.

Rochelle King is Global VP of User Experience and Design at Spotify, where she manages the teams that are responsible for user research and designing the product experience at Spotify. Prior to Spotify, King was VP of User Experience and Product Services at Netflix, where she managed the Design, Enhanced Content, Content Marketing and Localization teams.
Martin Reeves is chairman of the BCG Henderson Institute (BHI), BCG's think tank for new ideas in strategy and management.

Kristi Rogers is a core member of BCG’s Technology, Media and Telecommunications practice. Prior to joining BCG, Rogers spent eight years at Philips working in the US and Europe to build her career in corporate finance and consumer goods, last holding roles as Finance Director for Central and Eastern Europe and Lean Six Sigma Black Belt. She holds a BA from the University of Washington and an MBA from New York University.

Antonella Mei-Pochtler is a Senior Advisor for the Media and Consumer Goods sector based in Munich. She grew up in Rome, went to the Deutsche Schule Rom, studied Business Administration at the Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität in Munich with a grant from the DAAD and acquired her Doctoral degree at Università degli Studi di Roma. She holds an MBA from INSEAD, Fontainebleau, with the Dean’s List Award. She serves on the boards of Teach for All, DKMS and Phorms.
At Yahoo! Labs in Barcelona, Daniele Quercia and his colleagues imagine new ways to use online maps to improve our lives.

Julia Kloiber is Project Lead at the Open Knowledge Foundation Germany. She has a background in design and media theory and works on civic tech and open data projects. Her latest projects include a civic tech incubator Stadt Land Code and the community program Code for Germany.

Anil Raj is the Managing Director at OMC Power, a firm working to bring electricity to India’s rural villages by building micropower plants. A veteran of the telecom industry, Raj started India’s first mobile network in his role as the start-up CEO of Hutchinson Max Telecom in India. He later went on to Ericsson, where he held a number of senior management positions and established the company as a market leader in Indonesia and India.

Sarah Cairns-Smith is a Senior Advisor at BCG, based in Boston. She has worked across a broad variety of sectors in global development and health including water, sanitation and hygiene; financial services and education; mobile and big data; agriculture; and health product research, development and delivery. She received her PhD in Biochemistry from the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, London and MBA (Distinction) from Columbia Business School.

Mikael Fogelstrom is a Professor in theoretical physics and a Scientific Leader of the Graphene Centre at Chalmers University of Technology. His main topics of research are mesoscopic and unconventional superconductivity. Recently, he has added research on graphene and topological materials to his portfolio.

Karalee Close is a Managing Director and Partner in the London office of Boston Consulting Group and leads the Technology Advantage practice globally. Prior to joining BCG, Close worked in hospital management. She was Director of Corporate Planning at the University Health Network and Director of Customer Service at The Toronto Hospital. Karalee holds an MBA from University of Toronto and a BSc in Health Information Science from the University of Victoria.

Patrick Forth is a Senior Partner at BCG, based in Sydney. Previously, he opened and led BCG’s Singapore office and led BCG’s Australia and New Zealand business. He is also on the Board of BCG Digital Ventures. Prior to joining BCG, Patrick obtained a First Class Honours degree in Aeronautical Engineering at Manchester University, followed by a doctorate in turbomachinery at Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar.
An international performer, choreographer, educator and speaker, Andrew Nemr explores tap dance as a vehicle for storytelling and community building.
Through his startup Rainforest Connection, Topher White transforms used cell phones into guardians of the rainforest.

Nizar Ibrahim scours Northern Africa for clues to what things were like there in the Cretaceous period. A 2015 TED Fellow, he has spearheaded the recent search for the semi-aquatic dinosaur Spinosaurus.
Artist Brian Dettmer digs into a good book (literally, with a knife) to create beautifully intricate forms that reflect how we see old information in a modern world.
Jaap de Roode studies the ecology and evolution of parasites, focusing on those that attack the monarch butterfly.
Sarah Bergbreiter packs advanced technologies into tiny robots that can overcome obstacles 80 times their height.
Kenneth Shinozuka designs smart products ... He's been doing so since he was in kindergarten.

Fredy Peccerelli works with families whose loved ones “disappeared” in the 36-year armed conflict in Guatemala. The executive director of the Guatemalan Forensic Anthropology Foundation, he helps locate bodies and give back identities to those buried in mass graves.

Paul O'Connell is president and partner of FDO Partners, LLC, an investment management and research firm currently managing US$2.3 billion. FDO is a joint venture partner with State Street Associates. A native of Ireland, O'Connell has a B.A. from Trinity College, Dublin, and a Ph.D. in Economics from Harvard University. He’s also written and published many articles on global finance and capital allocation topics. And he serves as a director of the GAVI Campaign, which works to expand access to immunization, and chairs its Board.

Timothy Graf leads State Street’s Global Markets’ Macro Strategy team in Europe. His research focuses on the dynamics and trends in developed world economies and the implications they have for global currency and interest rate markets. Incorporating the views built in this process with insights from the world of behavioural finance, he regularly consults with many of the world’s largest institutional investors.

Todd Gershkowitz is the head of Global Total Rewards and Shared Services within Global Human Resources at State Street. He’s previously held senior positions at Citigroup, GE, IBM, UBS and with two consulting firms, and has spent about half of his career living and working internationally in Hong Kong, Singapore, the United Kingdom and Switzerland. His professional experiences have inspired his ideas for innovative ways to incentivize and reward employees.

Yusuf Nurbhai is the Chief Administrative Officer for Global Markets in EMEA, responsible for administrative management and coordination of deliverables to global leaders. His career at State Street ranges from research to foreign exchange.

Ashwini Mrinal Bhagat is a part of the Global Human Resources team for State Street India, specialising in talent management and employee relations. She believes in creating new platforms for learning and is passionate about employee engagement. She’s also an ardent writer and contributes to daily newspapers and blogs on topics related to current affairs and human resources.

Patrice Thompson is a permanent member of the Request for Proposal EMEA team, whose aim is to create effective marketing documents that promote products and services for institutional clients. As a graduate from the London School of Economics with a B.Sc. in Government and Economics, Thompson completed three rotations in the Professional Development Program in Foreign Exchange Sales and Trading, Transition Management, and the Regulatory Reform Project Management Office.
A human resources activist, Morgana Bailey wants to see the diversity of society reflected in the workplace, and employees of all walks of life feel comfortable being open about who they are.
2012 World Poetry Slam Champion Harry Baker has travelled the world off the strength of his way with words. He combines the nerdiness of being a math student with the hopefulness of being a human.

Thea Knight, a member of the State Street Internal Communications team, is out to eliminate jargon from the corporate consciousness and provide techniques we can use to make our conversations more productive. Formerly trained as a reporter, Knight is focused on simplifying the way we speak to each other.

John O'Leary thinks that we don’t take our conversations in business seriously. Within his role as director of communications of State Street’s business transformation programs, he seeks to remove the barriers that prevent healthy conversation in business. O’Leary is also co-authour of the 2009 best-selling book, “If We Can Put a Man on the Moon” and his writings have appeared in The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post, among others.

Christina Balch is a multimedia artist inspired by feminism, technology and human perceptions. Trained in drawing and painting, her interests have shifted to commonly used technologies like smart phones and social media as new tools for creating art. Balch works as an interactive producer, managing mobile and interactive digital products.

Since migrating from Singapore at the age of 10, Ma Shwe Sin Win (Cynthia) has noticed how much names impact on how we interact with one another. From school to boardroom, she has made it a point to reflect on what happens when we enforce norms each day. Win manages relationships of FX Connect and Currenex clients for State Street Global Exchange in South East Asia. She’s also a committee member with the Professional Women’s Network of State Street Singapore.

Avid Shakespearean John Bolton manages State Street’s thought leadership global program. In his role, he helps the organization to engage with clients and influencers through insights and stories that are powerful and engaging.
David Grady is on a crusade to help you take back your calendar.

No one knows a good ghost town than Abbey Williams. As those once bustling towns continue to litter the American landscape with its skeletal-like structures, Williams can’t help but wonder what’s to become of our habitats. After interning at State Street Global Advisors for two summers, Williams returned to provide administrative support to the Institutional Client Group’s Mid-Atlantic Relationship Management team.
Dr. Romina Libster investigates influenza and other respiratory viruses, searching for ways to most effectively keep viruses from spreading.
Cristina Domenech proposes to use language as an instrument of liberation and as a way to change the world.
Eduardo Sáenz de Cabezón links science with humor and stories.
Nancy Frates and her family have raised a projected $160 million for ALS research in 2014. How? They kicked off the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge to honor 29-year-old Pete Frates.
Social psychologist Emily Balcetis explores perception, motivation, goal-setting and decision-making from conscious and nonconscious levels.
Thomas Hellum is an award-winning television producer who works at NRK Hordaland in Norway.
Vernā Myers is dedicated to promoting meaningful, lasting diversity in the workplace.
Jeremy Howard imagines how advanced machine learning can improve our lives.
In his provocative, mind-bending book "The Secret Life of the Mind," neuroscientist Mariano Sigman reveals his life’s work exploring the inner workings of the human brain.
Carol Dweck is a pioneering researcher in the field of motivation, why people succeed (or don't) and how to foster success.
Mundano's bold, colorful street art isn't just eye candy. His projects call attention to social, environmental and political issues, while raising chuckles from passersby.
Computer scientist Michael Rubinstein and his team have developed a "motion microscope" that can show video footage of barely perceivable movements, like breaths and heartbeats.
Vincent Cochetel is the Director of the Bureau for Europe at the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR).
As the originator of the iPod, Tony Fadell is no stranger to disruptive technology. With Nest, he’s zeroed in on tech’s most elusive targets: household appliances.
Whether they’re sung in in English or his native Faroese, Teitur laces his deceptively innocent songs with often stinging hooks.
By challenging long-held legal notions of “personhood”, Steven Wise seeks to grant cognitively advanced animals access to a full spectrum of fundamental rights.
While exploring the neuroscience of speech and vocal behavior, Sophie Scott stumbled upon a surprising second vocation: making audiences laugh as a stand-up comic.
When he’s not ferreting out the links between stem cells and malignant blood disease, Siddhartha Mukherjee writes and lectures on the history (and future) of medicine.
With the runaway success of shows like Scandal and Grey’s Anatomy, Shonda Rhimes has become one of Hollywood’s most powerful icons.
Sara Seager’s research led to the first discovery of an atmosphere on a planet outside our solar system. Now she’s on the hunt for a twin Earth.
With his show 99% Invisible, Roman Mars discovered new ways to jolt public radio out of its old paradigms, while at the same time spinning riveting tales of design.
Embracing both genetically improved seed and ecologically based farming methods, Pamela Ronald aims to enhance sustainable agriculture.
Noy Thrupkaew reports on human trafficking and the economics of exploitation through the lens of labor rights.
From the micro scale to the building scale, Neri Oxman imagines and creates structures and objects that are inspired, informed and engineered by, for and with nature.
To determine how life might persist on Mars, Nathalie Cabrol explores one of Earth’s most extreme environments: high-elevation Andean lakes and deserts.
Monica Lewinsky advocates for a safer and more compassionate social media environment, drawing from her unique experiences at the epicenter of a media maelstrom in 1998.
Maryn McKenna recounts the often terrifying stories behind emerging drug-resistant diseases that medical science is barely keeping at bay.
Whether she’s inventing satellite radio, developing life-saving drugs or digitizing the human mind, Martine Rothblatt has a knack for turning visionary ideas into commonplace technology.
In her performances she’s been cut, burned, and nearly shot -- but Marina Abramović's boldest work yet is a gargantuan institute dedicated to transformation through art.
Developmental behavior studies spearheaded by Laura Schulz are changing our notions of how children learn.
While studying future alternatives for China’s global relations, former Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd has come to an ominous conclusion: conflict is looming.
After astonishing success as a mathematician, code breaker and billionaire hedge fund manager, Jim Simons is mastering yet another field: philanthropy.
As founder of International Justice Mission, Gary Haugen fights the chronically neglected global epidemic of violence against the poor.
As manager of the Rosetta mission, Fred Jansen is in charge of the project that could be instrumental in uncovering clues to the origins of life on Earth.
Acclaimed for his monumental “sculptural paintings,” Dustin Yellin now nurtures voices in the art community with Pioneer Works, his mammoth Brooklyn art center.
Donald Hoffman studies how our visual perception, guided by millions of years of natural selection, authors every aspect of our everyday reality.
With books and strategies, David Rothkopf helps people navigate the perils and opportunities of our contemporary geopolitical landscape.
David Eagleman decodes the mysteries of the tangled web of neurons and electricity that make our minds tick -- and also make us human.
Over thousands of archived and broadcast interviews, StoryCorps founder Dave Isay -- winner of the 2015 TED Prize -- has created an unprecedented document of the dreams and fears that touch us all.
Chris Burkard travels to remote, risky and often icy locations to capture stunning images that turn traditional surf photography on its head.
Using empathy and a clear-eyed view of mortality, BJ Miller shines a light on healthcare’s most ignored facet: preparing for death.
Anand Giridharadas writes about people and cultures caught amid the great forces of our time.
Alice Goffman’s fieldwork in a struggling Philadelphia neighborhood sheds harsh light on a justice system that creates suspects rather than citizens.
Alan Eustace leapt to Earth from the edge of the stratosphere wearing only a spacesuit, shattering skydiving records and potentially revolutionizing the commercial space industry.
Computer vision expert Abe Davis pioneers methods to extract audio from silent digital videos, even footage shot on ordinary consumer cameras.
Daniel Kish expands the perceptual toolbox of both blind and sighted humans by teaching echolocation -- the ability to observe our surroundings via sound.
Khadija Gbla is an award-winning inspirational speaker, facilitator and cross-cultural consultant. She is a former refugee from Sierra Leone currently living in Australia.
Rodrigo y Gabriela fuse metal, jazz and world music into an exhilarating cocktail of complex arrangements and virtuoso musicianship.
Stacey Baker assigns photography for the wide-ranging vision of the weekly New York Times Magazine.
Anand Varma's photos tell the story behind the science on everything from primate behavior and hummingbird biomechanics to amphibian disease and forest ecology.
Latif Nasser is the director of research at Radiolab, where he has reported on such disparate topics as culture-bound illnesses, snowflake photography, sinking islands and 16th-century automata.
Steve Silberman is a writer and contributing editor for Wired who covers science and society. His newest book explores neurodiversity and the link between autism and genius.
Dawn Landes, with her bright, supple voice and her restless imagination, is drawn to create and collaborate. A master of singer-songwriter pop, she is now writing a musical called "Row."

Suki Kim's investigation, "Without You, There Is No Us: My Time with the Sons of North Korea's Elite," chronicles her six months undercover in Pyongyang during Kim Jong-Il's final six months. She worked as a teacher and a missionary in a university for future leaders -- all while writing her book.
As Director of Stanford’s Artificial Intelligence Lab and Vision Lab, Fei-Fei Li is working to solve AI’s trickiest problems -- including image recognition, learning and language processing.
Using advanced data analysis tools, Rajiv Maheswaran and Second Spectrum help make basketball teams smarter.
The CEO of Carbon3D, Joseph DeSimone has made breakthrough contributions to the field of 3D printing.
A key player in the "Boston miracle" that lowered the rate of youth crime and gang violence, Rev. Jeffrey Brown is a Baptist minister.
Ben Ambridge is the author of "Psy-Q," a sparkling book debunking what we think we know about psychology.
Guy Winch asks us to take our emotional health as seriously as we take our physical health -- and explores how to heal from common heartaches.
2014 Nobel Peace Prize winner Kailash Satyarthi is a tireless activist fighting to protect the rights of voiceless children everywhere.
Nadine Burke Harris’ healthcare practice focuses on a little-understood, yet very common factor in childhood that can profoundly impact adult-onset disease: trauma.
Chris Umson is the Director of Self-Driving Cars at Google[x].
After setting a record for sailing around the world, Dame Ellen MacArthur has turned her attention toward creating a more "circular" economy -- where resources and power recirculate and regenerate.
Young piano player Joey Alexander has an old soul's gift for jazz.
James A. White Sr. believes that every person and organization has incredible potential. He works to help them understand it — and communicate it to others.
Ben Wellington blends his love of statistics, the city, and comedy in his entertaining analysis of the story of New York City, told through data.
Paul Jones is founder of Tudor Investment Corporation and an active philanthropist.
Cultivating the power of sustainable materials, Elora Hardy leads Ibuku, creating bespoke bamboo homes in her native Bali.

Theaster Gates is a potter whose ambitions stretch far beyond the wheel and the kiln. In Chicago, his leadership of artist-led spaces has catalyzed interest and excitement in a formerly neglected neighborhood, as he uses culture as a transformational weapon.
Tal Danino explores the emerging frontier of combining biology and engineering (and art). He is a 2015 TED Fellow.
Lee Mokobe is a 20-year-old South African slam poet and co-founder of Vocal Revolutionaries.
TED Senior Fellow Laura Boykin uses technology to help farmers in East Africa have more food to feed their families.

Jedidah Isler studies blazars — supermassive hyperactive black holes that emit powerful jet streams. They are the universe’s most efficient particle accelerators, transferring energy throughout galaxies.
From a plant that lives or dies based on stock prices to an oilcan that flows backward, Matt Kenyon creates art that startles, amuses and challenges assumptions.
Cosmin Mihaiu is the CEO and co-founder of MIRA Rehab, which develops software that engages patients in interactive and therapeutic games, making physical rehabilitation fun.
Benedetta Berti studies how conflicts impact civilians.
Aomawa Shields studies the climate and habitability of planets outside of the Solar System.
Stand-up comedian Negin Farsad counters Islamophobia in funny and clever ways.
An investigative journalist who reports on the FBI’s misuse of informants in counterterrorism operations, Trevor Aaronson asks the question: Is the United States catching terrorists or creating them?
Camille A. Brown leads her dance company through excavations of ancestral stories, both timeless and traditional, that connect history with contemporary culture.
Danielle N. Lee examines the ecology and natural history of nuisance rodents, using hip-hop to share science with broader audiences.
Patience Mthunzi wants to use lasers to deliver medicines more effectively.
French-Tunisian artist eL Seed blends the historic art of Arabic calligraphy with graffti to portray messages of beauty, poetry and peace across all continents.
TED Senior Fellow Kristen Marhaver is a marine biologist studying the ecology, behavior and reproduction of reef corals.
LaToya Ruby Frazier focuses her camera lens on working class families, exploring themes of family, inequality, health care and environmental racism.
Prison reform advocate Ismael Nazario helps former inmates from New York's Rikers Island jail reenter society.
Shimpei Takahashi thinks we should forget about analyzing data or sales figures and just come up with ideas -- lots and lots of ideas.
Linda Hill studies collective genius -- the way great companies, and great leaders, empower creativity from many.
Working at the frontiers of interactive technology, Chris Milk stretches virtual reality into a new canvas for storytelling.
Robyn Stein DeLuca asks, What do we really know about PMS?
Achenyo Idachaba is the head of MitiMeth, a Nigeria-based company that makes handicrafts from aquatic weeds and other agro-waste.
Alaa Murabit champions women’s participation in peace processes and conflict mediation.
Alix Generous is a college student and biology researcher with Asperger syndrome. She stresses the importance of building accepting environments for all kinds of minds.
As abortion debates have turned black-and-white, Aspen Baker advocates being "pro-voice" -- listening respectfully and compassionately to all kinds of experiences.
Billie Jean King won 39 Grand Slam titles during her tennis career, and has long been a pioneer for equality and social justice.
Elizabeth Nyamayaro is the Senior Advisor to the Under Secretary-General and Executive Director of UN Women, as well as head of UN Women's blockbuster HeForShe initiative.
The president of the United States from 1977 to 1981, Jimmy Carter has used his post-presidency years to work for peace, teach, write and engage in global activism.
As a Philadelphia high school principal, Linda Cliatt-Wayman held an unwavering belief in the potential of all children.
Marlene Zuk studies insect behavior -- and how humans use animal behavior to think about how we behave ourselves.
Mary Robinson served as president of Ireland from 1990 to 1997, and as UN High Commissioner for Human Rights from 1997 to 2002. She now leads a foundation devoted to climate justice.
Mia Birdsong advocates for strong communities and the self-determination of everyday people.
The author of "Angry White Men," Michael Kimmel is a pre-eminent scholar of men and masculinity.
Barat Ali Batoor, an award-winning photojournalist, is a member of the Hazara people. He is based in Australia.
Nonny de la Peña uses new, immersive media to tell stories that create empathy in readers and viewers.
Pardis Sabeti investigates the genomes of microbes, like Ebola and coronavirus, to understand how to slow them.
What if a computer could recognize your facial expression, and react to how you feel? Rana el Kaliouby sees big possibilities in making technology emotionally aware.
The author of "Whitopia," Rich Benjamin sharply observes modern society and politics.
The former editor-in-chief of Ms., Robin Morgan published the classic "Sisterhood Is Powerful" anthologies.
In "Bad Feminist," her 2014 book of essays, Roxane Gay laid out a wise, funny and deeply empathetic vision of modern feminism, acceptance and identity -- flaws and all.
At the Afghan Institute of Learning, Sakena Yacoobi provides teacher training to Afghan women, supporting education for girls and boys throughout the country.
Originally from New Orleans, Louisiana, Sunni Patterson combines the heritage, culture, and traditions of her native town with a spiritual worldview to create powerful music and poetry.
Robin Murphy researches robots -- ground, aerial and marine -- that can help out during disasters.
Architect Takaharu Tezuka creates imaginative and versatile personal spaces.
Jenni Chang and Lisa Dazols made "Out & Around" to show the momentous changes in the status of LGBTQ equality -- all around the world.
Memory Banda is a tireless leader for girls’ rights, in Malawi and around the world.
With his artistry and creativity, Bill T. Jones has inspired a generation of dancers, choreographers -- and audiences.
What makes us incessantly check our phones? Adam Alter dives into the fascinating psychology that drives our tech addictions.
A life sentence in Pennsylvania means exactly that; there is no possibility of parole. These women, all of whom have served decades in prison, sing about their lives on the inside.
Yassmin Abdel-Magied wears many hats, including a hijab. She's a mechanical engineer, writer and activist who campaigns for tolerance and diversity.
In his book "Homo Deus," Yuval Noah Harari explores the future of humankind: the destinies we may set for ourselves and the quests we'll undertake.
Climate researcher Alice Bows-Larkin connects her academic research to the broader policy context, helping create policies to deal with our changing planet.
Frances Larson explores the dark and varied obsessions that our culture has had with decapitated heads and skulls throughout history.
Johann Hari is the author of two "New York Times" best-selling books.
In his book "The Dark Net," Jamie Bartlett investigates Internet subcultures, both legal and illegal.
Rodrigo Bijou's work focuses on the cross section of intelligence, data science and information security.
At his lab at Stanford School of Medicine, Tony Wyss-Coray studies aging -- and potential cures for it.
Physicist Jim Al-Khalili and co-author Johnjoe McFadden, a biologist, explore the far edges of quantum biology in their book "Life on the Edge."

Douglas Beal is a Partner and Director in BCG's Social Impact practice and serves as a Global Leader of the Total Societal Impact Initiative. His experience and expertise include national development strategies, sector development strategies and enablers of overall economic and socioeconomic progress. He earned his Bachelor in Science from Cornell University and an MBA from Columbia University.

Mathieu Lamiaux is a Senior Partner and Managing Director in the Paris office of BCG with more than 15 years of experience working with governments, international institutions, NGOs, civil society and private sector to improve access to care in emerging economies. He also advises the World Economic Forum on a multi-year project to explore the development of efficient and effective health systems in emerging economies.
Samuel Cohen researches Alzheimer's disease and other neurodegenerative disorders.
Sandrine Thuret studies the way adult brains create new nerve cells in the hippocampus -- a brain area involved in memory and mood.

A former Partner at BCG, Philip Krinks is a Deacon in the Church of England and currently Assistant Curate at St Mary’s Battersea in London, where he shares in the spiritual care of a diverse urban community. He is the Founder and Chairman of St. Martin’s Affordable Finance Development, a charity devoted to developing solutions for the high-cost credit market in the UK, driven by a Christian ethos.
Patty McCord served as chief talent officer of Netflix for 14 years and helped create the Netflix Culture Deck.

Vikram Bhalla is a Senior Partner and Managing Director in the Mumbai office of BCG. He leads BCG’s Family Business topic globally, as well as its Leadership and Talent topic. Bhalla is the author of several publications including: "Succeeding with Succession Planning in Family Businesses" and "Governance for Family Business: Sustaining the 'Magic' for Generations to Come." His work was featured in The Economist’s Dynasties edition.

Markus Lorenz is a Managing Director and Senior Partner in BCG’s Munich office and a core member of the Industrial Goods and Operations practices, with a focus on machinery and automation components. Lorenz studied industrial engineering at the University of Karlsruhe, holds an MBA from Vanderbilt University and earned a PhD in Mechanical Engineering from the Technical University Munich.

Joachim Horn transformed the complicated process of creating smart devices and products by empowering everyone to become an instant innovator. A mechanical engineering graduate and co-founder of the Imperial College Design Collective, Horn fused his passion for design and tech to develop SAM Labs. SAM, dubbed the “Lego of the Internet generation,” is the world’s most engaging Internet of Things toolset, giving users tools to become inventors.

Sarah Willersdorf is a Managing Director and Partner in the New York office of BCG and serves as a topic expert on Fashion and Luxury. She advises CEOs and leadership teams across a range of topics surrounding growth, including branding transformation, marketing effectiveness, digital optimization, international expansion and more. She has an MBA from INSEAD and a Bachelor in Commerce and Bachelor in Fine Art from the University of Melbourne, Australia.

Emma Bridgewater has become a household name known for her sprightly, family-inspired pottery. Bridgewater studied English at London University, establishing the company in London and Stoke-on-Trent with no formal business training. With a passionate refusal to outsource manufacturing abroad, she has become a champion of British manufacturing, spearheading the revival in traditional craft in Stoke-on-Trent, the historical home of British pottery.

Luc de Brabandere is a fellow and Senior Advisor with BCG, specializing in applying creativity and strategic vision techniques to business. He is a professor at the Louvain School of Management and the Ecole Centrale in Paris. He is the author or co-author of a dozen books including "The Forgotten Half of Change" and "Thinking in New Boxes."

Diana Dosik is a Partner based in the New York office of BCG. She works primarily on healthcare and organizational projects with a specialization in pharmaceuticals and organizational behaviour. In 2008, Dosik spent seven months in the London chapter of Save The Children, where she led a program that reunified families across geographies. She graduated from Harvard Business School and Yale University with a BA in History of Science and Medicine.

Shalini Unnikrishnan is a Partner in the Chicago office of BCG and sits on the US Board of Directors of the Tony Blair Africa Governance Initiative. In 2014, Unnikrishnan provided on-the-ground support in the creation of the UN Mission for Ebola Emergency Response to handle the escalating crisis. She holds an MBA in Healthcare Management from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania and a Masters in International Relations from SAIS Johns Hopkins University.
Knut Haanaes believes that the secret to creating lasting, impactful companies is to find a balance between doing what you're good at and looking for new challenges to take on.
The author of "The Fault in Our Stars" and "Paper Towns," John Green is a passionate online video maker.
Through visual art, composition and performance, Christine Sun Kim explores ways of transmuting sound and silence.
Genevieve von Petzinger studies the geometric signs found in early European Ice Age rock art sites.
Chelsea Shields is a biocultural anthropologist, a research and strategy consultant, and an outspoken activist for women's rights.

As the VP of Global Logistics and Marketing, Alan Amling oversees marketing efforts for UPS’s global logistics and distribution services. Most of his tenure with UPS has been spent in development roles, with six years building out e-commerce capabilities and another six years in new product development, where he oversaw the rise of some of UPS’s largest product and marketing initiatives. He began his UPS career in 1982 working as a seasonal employee loading and unloading package feeders before joining UPS in 1992.

Esther Ndichu is responsible for the UPS Foundation’s global humanitarian engagements, where she manages solutions, operations and support resources for external partners as they prepare for and respond to disasters. Born in Nairobi, Kenya, Ndichu understands first-hand some of the challenges the humanitarian organizations face when delivering aid and relief, which has grown into a vested interest in seeing UPS expand into Africa and the humanitarian sector.

Starting in 2003, Jack Levis led the development of ORION, an optimized routing system that's systematically transforming how UPS drivers do their jobs. As the senior director of process management at UPS, Levis considers how a massive company can use radical technologies to improve operations on a grand scale. By developing a routing system that determines the most efficient delivery route for every driver, Levis and his team will take more than 100 million miles off the road every year.

Jared Hill currently flies the MD-11 for UPS, for which he received the “Aircrew of the Year” award in 2014. But outside of work, his passions lie with a group of orphans at Restoration Gateway in Northern Uganda, where he recently taught math to grades three through six and now sits on their Board of Directors.

During the day, Johnny Staats is a UPS driver. At all other times, he is a world-class bluegrass mandolin, guitar and violin player. He has appeared on stage at the Grand Ole Opry five times and won Charleston’s Vandalia Gathering Mandolin Championships in 1996, 1997, and 1999 -- in 1997, he also won the guitar title and placed third in the fiddle competition. Staats's most recent album, "Time Moves On," with his band the Delivery Boys, features contemporary bluegrass combined with country and blues influences.

With a steadfast commitment to a single path that's rarely seen, Kelly Lepley has grown from pointing at pictures of airplanes in every book she could find to flying one of the largest cargo planes that UPS holds. In stark contrast, her personal life follows a complex and twisting path. Riddled with the shadows of deception and self-doubt, she is familiar with the painful stops, starts, and questions that come with becoming who you are.

A seasoned logistics executive, Kevin Etter has spent 32 years in positions at UPS that range from healthcare strategy to industrial engineering. His varied expertise are now on loan to GAVI, a non-profit that increases global access to vaccines. Through his work at Gavi, he has experienced first-hand the unexpected benefits that come when companies donate what he believes are their most valuable assets: their employees.

From 1990-1997, Laura Lane was a diplomat in the US Foreign Service, stationed at the American Embassy in Kigali, Rwanda. She led the evacuation effort of American citizens in April 1994 with the outbreak of civil war. Later, she returned as a political advisor to US forces, providing humanitarian relief to Rwandan refugees. Lane currently serves as president of global public affairs for UPS.

Mark Modesti uses his expertise from working within UPS’s walls to improve supply chains within other companies. His professional responsibility to shake up organizational systems puts him in a constant collision course with the undeniably human resistance to change. Through this, Modesti has learned time and time again that the greatest value always comes after the greatest trials, tribulations -- and trouble.

As the director of sustainability for UPS’s businesses in Europe, Peter Harris pursues innovations that turn risks into opportunities. He has served as UPS's UK automotive director, UK industrial engineering director and as a senior manager in corporate compliance. He is also a director of a small company providing transport services to the UK’s National Health Service.
Regina Hartley thinks that those who don't always look good on paper may be just the person you need to hire.

With a palpable passion for the unpredictability of global trade, Scott Szwast has spent the last 25 years supporting international transportation. For 10 of them, he worked with an ocean freight line, helping to import and export goods. The last 15 years he has spent with UPS, deep-diving into distribution, transportation, technology, trade compliance and the countless other aspects of cross-border trade. Today, he is a marketing director for UPS, where he works closely with companies expanding into new markets to understand the particular needs of growing organizations and to develop the solutions to support them.

Yami Joshi is an organizational development specialist at UPS, where she develops and implements organizational strategies to improve the employee experience. Deeply involved in UPS’s Women’s Leadership Development Group, Joshi dedicates herself to learning how she can grow leadership capabilities in others. Outside of her work and studies, she's a certified Indian classical dancer, specializing in the dance form Bharatanatyam, which she has taught to students between the ages of 5 and 12.
Mandy Len Catron explores love stories.
Scott Dinsmore founded Live Your Legend, a career and connection platform to inspire people to find their passion.
Ole Scheeren designs buildings that generate both functional and social spaces.
Hilary Cottam wants to redesign the welfare state using the power of relationships.
For the Norwegian newspaper Dagbladet, Anders Fjellberg investigated the story of "The Wetsuitman," along with his co-author, photographer Tomm Christiansen.
Daniel Levitin incorporates findings from neuroscience into everyday life.
Jennifer Doudna was part of inventing a potentially world-changing genetic technology: the gene editing technology CRISPR-Cas9.
Ann Morgan challenged herself to read a book from every country in the world.
The work of artists Mathias Jud and Christoph Wachter questions the limits of our communication possibilities and, therefore, of our identity.
Francesco Sauro studies caves and other karst features, and his research takes him places no one has ever been before.
Florida-based photographer Mac Stone specializes in documenting the Everglades, an area he prizes for its wildlife and flora.

At age 12, Martin Pistorius fell into a coma, and spent 13 years locked inside his body, unable to communicate -- until a caregiver noticed his eyes responded to her. His book "Ghost Boy" tells his story.
Emilie Wapnick celebrates the "multipotentialite" -- those of us with many interests, many jobs over a lifetime, and many interlocking potentials.
Maurice Conti explores new partnerships between technology, nature and humanity.
Thomas Peschak strives to merge photojournalism and cutting edge science to create powerful media projects that tackle critical marine conservation issues.
Mike Velings understands the potential for business to create durable solutions to complex world problems.
Jason deCaires Taylor's underwater installations offer views of another world, where the artistic efforts of man meet the vivifying power of nature.

speaker_occupation: Marine biologist and President of Project CETI
speaker_description: David Gruber and his team take a delicate approach to understanding whales and other life forms.
Paul Greenberg researches and writes about fish, aquaculture and the future of the ocean.

speaker_occupation: President of the Republic of Kiribati
speaker_description: Anote Tong has built worldwide awareness of the potentially devastating impacts of climate change.
Josh Luber is the founder of Campless, a company that collects, analyzes and publishes data and derived insight related to collectible sneakers and the industry.

Dr. Jeannette Garcia designs new polymers through sustainable methods, with potential usage as structural composites, cargo carriers, adhesives, sealants and 3D printing. Garcia's team also uses discarded bottles to create materials, and they designed a low-cost, portable detection system for water toxins. In addition, she researches energy storage for automotive batteries and has interests in chemistries for improving the environment and human health.

Dr. Jerry M. Chow, Manager of Experimental Quantum Computing at IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, is IBM’s primary investigator for IARPA’s Multi-Qubit Coherent Operations. Jerry graduated magna cum laude from Harvard with a B.A. in physics and an M.S. in applied mathematics and from Yale with an M.S. and Ph.D. in physics. He received an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship for his quantum processor with superconducting qubits work.

Vinith Misra of IBM’s Watson Group boasts research interests from knowledge graph prediction and The Lord of the Rings analytics to data-driven compression and theoretic models. Recipient of the Stanford Graduate Fellowship, National Science and Defense Graduate Fellowship and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s David Adler Memorial Thesis Prize, he is a member of Forbes’ “30 Under 30” (2015) and consults on HBO’s "Silicon Valley." Vinith holds a Ph.D. from Stanford’s Information Systems Lab and an S.B. and M.Eng. from MIT.

Jared Kleinert is co-author of "2 Billion Under 20" and the founder of Kleinert Ventures, a marketing consulting firm helping leaders and companies market, recruit and retain millennials. He was a team member at 15Five and Learnist, and hesuccessfully started (and spectacularly failed at) two startups as a teenager.
Dr. Chieko Asakawa invents technology to make the visually impaired more independent.
Eric Mibuari studies the blockchain at IBM Research and is the founder of the Laare Community Technology Centre in Meru, Kenya.
Lisa Marie Johnston is a singer and songwriter from Oakland, CA. She blends country, Americana and blues to a “stomp and groove” style.

Dr. Robert Prill is a Computational Biologist at the IBM Almaden Research Center in California. He is an expert at combining genomic, phenotypic and metadata into integrative analyses evoking concepts from systems biology, machine learning, data science and visualization. Receiving a Ph.D. in Biomedical Engineering from the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine (2008), Prill currently leads an interdisciplinary team of engineers and scientists in pursuit of microbial biomarkers for food safety.

Dr. Maria Dubovitskaya is a staff member at IBM Research Zurich designing and applying cryptographic protocols for privacy protection. She holds a Ph.D. in cryptography and privacy from ETH Zurich. She promotes science and tech for young girls with IBM EX.I.T.E. (Exploring Interests in Technology and Engineering), is a founder and co-leader of IBM Technical Excellence Council R/CIS.

Shoel Perelman is the Vice President of Development for IBM’s Customer Engagement Solutions. His team -- spanning North America and Asia -- pioneers innovations converging at ecommerce, digital marketing, analytics and merchandising. Former Development Director for IBM’s Smarter Cities, he partnered with IBM research and launched software optimizing traffic flows, water usage and cities’ public safety response.

Lloyd A. Treinish, leader of the global environmental science team at IBM Research, is an author of 60+ technical articles and recipient of five patents. In his role at the IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Lloyd oversees research, development and operations with clients on five continents. He pioneered environmental business operations services including weather, water, energy, climate and sustainability. Treinish is considered the father of Deep Thunder for advanced modelling for weather-sensitive decision-making.

Dr. Kala Fleming, scientist and thought leader on water management, is an advisor for the government and private sector in Africa and SE Asia. Over the last 10 years, she worked with underserved communities in the U.S., Caribbean and West Africa as a consultant providing solutions focused on evolving communities. She leads a team of scientists at IBM Research – Africa on smarter planet solutions for water, agriculture and healthcare.

Aaron Horowitz is a maker. From sculptures to business, he is fascinated with taking ideas from concept to reality. He is co-founder and CEO of Sproutel and creator of Jerry the Bear -- a smart toy for health and wellness education. He holds a degree in Mechatronics and User Interaction Design from Northwestern University and serves on Design for America’s advisory board. When unplugged, Aaron is carving stone or surfing.
Nir Eyal writes, consults and teaches on the intersection of psychology, technology and business.
Alyson McGregor studies women's health, especially as it relates to emergency care -- when time-sensitive, life-or-death decisions are made using drugs and treatments mainly tested on men.

Tea Uglow leads part of Google's Creative Lab specializing in work with cultural organizations, artists, writers and producers on experiments using digital technology at the boundaries of traditional cultural practice.

Head of Quantextual Research at State Street Global Exchange, Stephen Lawrence has built his career around helping people understand research quickly and efficiently. At State Street, he oversees the development and execution of research aggregation by blending machine learning and big data with the contextual knowledge of human insight and oversight. His team’s “Idea Lab” helps summarize a wide range of research, including academic and sell-side research.

Suzanne Duncan is a senior vice president and the global head of research for State Street’s Center for Applied Research. She is passionate about creating and sharing new ideas, and she has won multiple awards for groundbreaking research and delivery.

Born in India and raised across three continents, Sahil Sethi believes capitalism should be a force for good and business should be done for the betterment of society. He is also passionate about getting charities and social organizations plugged into the enterprise economy to make them more sustainable. He works as a Defined Contribution Investment Strategist at State Street Global Advisors in London, helping clients deliver better defined contribution plans for their members.
Siawn Ou works on the Fund Services Custody team in State Street Sacramento and is the founder of the group Move Well on Collaborate.
Audrey Choi is a thought leader on how finance can be harnessed to address public policy challenges.

Whether you are an introvert or extrovert, diverse personalities are often a company’s biggest asset. But sometimes at work there's a struggle to balance personality with “executive presence.” Katherine Lucas is looking at solutions. Head of Marketing for North America at State Street, Lucas works closely with clients and internal teams to understand their challenges and provide direction for marketing programs.

Bridging Education and Art Together (B.E.A.T.) transforms the lives of youth in under-served areas through music, dance and writing programs which include beatboxing, B-boying and B-girling (breakdance), music production and composition, and creative writing.

Suzanne Case is a senior vice president at State Street, managing a global operations team that delivers solutions across a breadth of custody, banking and regulatory disciplines. A champion for inclusion, Case helps remove barriers to professional development through coaching, mentoring and company-wide executive sponsorships. She was recognized with State Street’s 2014 Black Professionals Group “Ambassador for Diversity and Inclusion Award” for outstanding leadership.

James Bickerton is a global FX business manager and front-office product designer, working in a close-knit team to deliver trading and sales strategies. He is focused on algorithmic execution for electronic and direct trading risk management and helping to manage the expansion of the European GmbH. Bickerton fuses innovative technologies with front-office trading and sales workflows to bring State Street into the future.

Kirsten Hall is a regulatory project manager within Global Markets at State Street, responsible for driving and implementing regulatory change projects. With an interest in the exercise of both social and economic power, Hall is fascinated by the many ways in which language can shape meaning, drive action and construct identities.

As a reformed perfectionist and former professional athlete, Charly Haversat began noticing that we spend a lot of our personal and professional lives on being flawless. But her big question is: As we obsess about perfection, are we actually getting anything done? A vice president in Alternative Investment Solutions, she focuses on designing scalable, cost-effective programs that meet both our business needs and our clients’ expectations.
Self-proclaimed knee activist Chris Vogtherr has begun the new manvolution -- the "Free the Knee" campaign. As a senior relationship manager for SSGA, he seeks to revolutinize the male office attire.
Andreas Ekström describes the power structures of the digital revolution.
Raymond Wang won the top prize in the 2015 Intel Science and Engineering Fair for his invention that circulates fresh air on planes and reduces transmission of germs between passengers.
Danit Peleg created the first 3D-printed fashion collection printed entirely using home printers.
Father-daughter beatboxing duo Nicole Paris and Ed Cage mix beats across generations.
Magda Sayeg uses handmade, eye-catching yarn bombs to shake up the way we see the world and make us notice things we hadn't seen before.
Jill Heinerth explores underwater caves deep inside the earth.
With just one breath, Guillaume Néry can dive to -125m below the water's surface.
Jean-Paul Mari has reported on conflicts in more than three dozen countries.
António Guterres is at the forefront of fighting the climate emergency and achieving the Sustainable Development Goals.
Jocelyne Bloch is helping to unlock potential self-healing capacities of the human brain.
Auke Ijspeert works at the intersection of robotics, biology and computational neuroscience.
Harry Cliff looks for answers to questions about the origins of the universe and the laws of nature.
Yanis Varoufakis thinks we need a radically new way of thinking about the economy, finance and capitalism.

speaker_occupation: Professor of molecular and cell biology
speaker_description: Jill Farrant is leading the development of drought-tolerant crops to nourish populations in arid climates.
Elizabeth Lev's experience studying and teaching art has led her to believe that when we encounter something beautiful, we are made vulnerable and opened to the truth.
Julie Lythcott-Haims speaks and writes on the phenomenon of helicopter parenting and the dangers of a checklisted childhood -- the subject of her book, "How to Raise an Adult."

Nadia Lopez is the founding principal of Mott Hall Bridges Academy, where she is showing the world how underprivileged communities can beat the odds and create positive institutions that have a global impact.
Dena Simmons believes that creating a safe environment for children is an essential component of education.
Broadway and TV veteran Sara Ramirez challenges stereotypes even as she beguiles audiences.
Victor Rios seeks to uncover how to best support the lives of young people who experience poverty, stigma and social exclusion.
Sam Kass's work connects nutrition and education in an effort to make sure future generations thrive.
Samantha Nutt envisions a world where no child knows war.
Adam Driver is working to bridge the cultural gap between the United States Armed Forces and the performing arts communities by bringing the best modern American theater to the military.
Jamila Raqib works on pragmatic approaches to nonviolent action for activists, human rights organizations, academics and governments globally.
Hector A. Garcia has spent his career as a frontline psychologist delivering evidence-based psychotherapies to veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
At Pixar, Danielle Feinberg delights in bending the rules of light to her every whim.
Zaria Forman uses visual art to connect people with the impact of climate change.
James Green leads NASA's solar system exploration and astrobiology research.
Paula Hammond, head of MIT's Department of Chemical Engineering, is developing new technologies to kill cancer cells.
Sangeeta Bhatia is a cancer researcher, MIT professor and biotech entrepreneur who works to adapt technologies developed in the computer industry for medical innovation.
Jessica Shortall is a working mom of two and author of Work. Pump. Repeat: The New Mom's Survival Guide to Breastfeeding and Going Back to Work.
Psychiatrist and addiction expert Judson Brewer researches mindfulness techniques that effectively help quell cravings of all kinds.
Melissa Walker helps military service members recover from traumatic brain injury and mental illness.
Mary Bassett is fighting what may be the greatest stumbling block to equitable health care in the US: institutional racism.
Russ Altman uses machine learning to better understand adverse effects of medication.
UCSD bioengineering professor Todd Coleman integratively spans the disciplines of medical electronics, machine learning and public health.
Sarah Gray found meaning in tragic loss­­ by donating the organs of her newborn son to advance scientific research.
Global scholar, University of Pennsylvania civil rights sociologist and law professor Dorothy Roberts exposes the myths of race-­based medicine.
Vanessa Ruiz documents the intersection of medical illustration and contemporary art.
Dr. Laura Robinson's scientific mission is to document and understand the processes that govern climate.
Floyd E. Romesberg uses chemistry, biology and physics to study how biomolecules work and to create biomolecules with new forms and functions.
Robert Waldinger is the Director of the Harvard Study of Adult Development, one of the most comprehensive longitudinal studies in history.
David Sedlak’s research focuses the long-term goal of developing cost-effective, safe and sustainable systems to manage water resources.

speaker_occupation: Chief of the Community Partnership Division
speaker_description: Melvin Russell is bringing stakeholders together to work toward the common goal of peace and prosperity for Baltimore City.
Sean Follmer designs shape-changing and deformable interfaces that take advantage of our natural dexterity and spatial abilities.
By shifting his focus from incarceration to transforming lives, Adam Foss is reinventing the role of the criminal prosecutor.
As Uber's co-founder and former CEO, Travis Kalanick is disrupting an entrenched industry and reinventing urban transportation.
By blending up to 100 still photographs into a seamless composite that captures the transition from day to night, Stephen Wilkes reveals the stories hidden in familiar locations.
Columnist and author Alice Rawsthorn illuminates the mesh of design woven into every aspect of our everyday lives and communities.
Novelist, writer, culture critic and playwright Monica Byrne thinks that there's an infinite number of stories to tell, and she intends to tell as many as she can.
Writer, producer and free-speech champion Norman Lear defined decades of US popular culture with his groundbreaking TV shows.
In her acclaimed novels and memoir, author Lidia Yuknavitch navigates the intersection of tragedy and violence to draw new roadmaps for self­-discovery.
Haley Van Dyck is building a startup at the White House and recruiting world-class technology talent to change how government works for the American people.
By cataloging every conceivable human skin tone, Angélica Dass illustrates that skin color and race are more complex than they might appear at first glance.
In his quest to understand the largest dinosaurs to have walked the Earth, Lacovara blends exploration with the latest imaging and modeling techniques from engineering to medicine.
As "Captain of Moonshots" for X, Astro Teller oversees the secret projects that could reshape our lives in coming decades.
Kang Lee has devoted his career to understanding the development of social cognition and behavior.
With a rich voice and an equally rich sense of history, Rhiannon Giddens animates American folk tradition with her electrifying song interpretations.
Kio Stark explores the myriad ways encounters with strangers impact our lives.
Cédric Villani tackles perplexing problems in mathematical physics, analysis and geometry with rigor, wit and a signature personal style.
When her hashtag #IfAfricaWasABar went viral, Botswana writer Siyanda Mohutsiwa triggered a lighthearted but electrifying discussion of some serious African issues.
One of Adam Grant’s guiding principles is to argue like he's right and listen like he's wrong.
With his latest invention, HoloLens, Kinect creator Alex Kipman has opened a virtual holographic universe for users to explore -- and he may have changed the face of computing forever.
Ameera Harouda leads journalists to the harrowing (and often hidden) stories of the Gaza Strip that they couldn’t find on their own.

speaker_occupation: Executive Director and Cofounder of One Acre Fund
speaker_description: With One Acre Fund, Andrew Youn fights poverty in rural sub-Saharan Africa.
As president of the American Enterprise Institute, Arthur Brooks is changing the way conservatives think about poverty and opportunity.
TED Senior Fellow Blitz Bazawule is a hip-hop artist and filmmaker who tells many-layered stories of an ever-evolving African diaspora.
Cambridge research professor Brian Little analyzes and redefines the threads of our personalities -- and suggests ways we can transform ourselves.
In his memoir, "There Will Be No Miracles Here," Casey Gerald reimagines what it means to truly live and succeed in our society.
As president of the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence, Dan Gross seeks to cut US gun deaths in half by 2025.
With his unique inventions (including a device knitted from threads of high-tech alloy by indigenous craftswomen), Franz Freudenthal saves children from congenital heart defects.
Through the Global Citizen platform, humanitarian Hugh Evans has created an online community of millions of people -- all driven to eradicate extreme poverty by the year 2030.
In articles that span the gene-editing abilities of CRISPR, the roots of psychopathic behavior in children, and much more, Jennifer Kahn weaves gripping stories from unlikely sources.
As a designer, entrepreneur and the co-founder and Chief Product Officer of Airbnb, Joe Gebbia helped redesign the way the world travels and people connect.
Using unexpected channels like the pulpit and the barber’s chair, Dr. Joseph Ravenell delivers basic health care information to an at-risk demographic -- African-American men.
In 1991, Linus Torvalds shared the Linux kernel with a few computer hobbyists. The operating system they built reshaped the software industry.
R. Luke DuBois weaves information from a multitude of sources into art and music exploring the tensions between algorithms, portraiture and temporal space.
As a copy editor for the New Yorker, Mary Norris enforces some of the most authoritative (some might say eccentric) style rules in publishing.
As co-founder and CEO of MASS Design Group, Michael Murphy envisions and creates  community-centric structures with healing built into their core.
Reshma Saujani, author of "Brave, Not Perfect" and founder of Girls Who Code, initiates young women into the tech world. Her goal: one million women in computer science by 2020.
Riccardo Sabatini applies his expertise in numerical modeling and data to projects ranging from material science to computational genomics and food market predictions.
With a repertoire spanning classical, improvisational and folk traditions from around the globe, the Silk Road Ensemble spins sounds that celebrate cultural solidarity.
Sō Percussion is building a new canon of modern avant-garde percussion music.
Sue Desmond-Hellmann leads the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation’s mission to establish equity for every person.
With Wait But Why, Tim Urban demonstrates that complex and long-form writing can stand out in an online wilderness choked with listicles and clickbait.
Tshering Tobgay is the president of the People's Democratic Party in Bhutan.
Why do great thoughts and stories resonate so strongly with so many people, and how do we communicate them? Using fMRI experiments, Uri Hasson is looking for the answers.
Judge Victoria Pratt is inspiring a global revolution in criminal justice.
While searching for ways to study stellar radiation without relying on sight, Wanda Diaz Merced has developed a way to represent complex data about our universe as sound.
Anthony Goldbloom crowdsources solutions to difficult problems using machine learning.
Tom Hulme's enthusiasm spans physics, design, entrepreneurship and investment.
Christiana Figueres is an internationally recognized leader on climate action and steered the global diplomatic effort that culminated in the 2015 Paris Agreement.
Oscar Schwartz's research and writing concerns the influence of digital technology on culture and human interaction.
Tania Simoncelli advises the White House on science and technology policy.
Linda Liukas wants to create a more diverse and colorful world of technology, starting with the poetry of code.
At Meta, Meron Gribetz is leading an effort to produce and sell augmented reality glasses with natural gestural hand recognition.
Tabetha Boyajian is best known for her research on KIC 8462852, a puzzling celestial body that has inspired otherwise sober scientists to brainstorm outlandish hypotheses.
Sisters Melati and Isabel Wijsen are on a mission to ban plastic bags in Bali.

speaker_occupation: Special Olympics International Sargent Shriver Global Messenger
speaker_description: Matthew Williams believes that sport has the power to change lives.
Gregory Heyworth uses spectral imaging technology to uncover lost classics that could rewrite history.
Ivan Coyote believes that a good story can help inspire us to invent a better future.
