Celeste Headlee's years of interview experience give her a unique perspective on what makes for a good conversation.
Alexander Betts explores ways societies might empower refugees rather than pushing them to the margins.
TED Senior Fellow Andrew Pelling uses novel materials for next-generation medical innovations and speculative living technologies of the future.
Keolu Fox explores the links between human genetic variation and disease in underrepresented populations.
Sanford Biggers creates art that upends traditional narratives about topics ranging from hip hop to Buddhism to American history.
Trevor Timm is the co-founder and executive director of Freedom of the Press Foundation, a non-profit organization that supports and defends journalism dedicated to transparency and accountability.
Shivani Siroya created a tool that allows anyone with a cell phone to build a financial track record.
Prosanta Chakrabarty studies fish to help explain the evolution of human beings and our planet.
Jessica Ladd is using technology to combat sexual assault, empower survivors and advance justice.
Safwat Saleem uses satire and art to bring to light stories of adversity.
Carrie Nugent is part of a team that uses NASA's NEOWISE telescope to search the skies for and catalog asteroids.
Laura Indolfi is revolutionizing cancer treatment with new technologies including implantable devices for delivering drugs locally to the site of a tumor.
Mileha Soneji believes that having empathy and being able to put yourself in another person's shoes is what makes for great design.
Carol Fishman Cohen documents successful transitions back into the workforce after career breaks.
Lisa Nip's work focuses on how we can use synthetic biology to allow humanity to explore space
Aditi Gupta uses storytelling and art to educate young girls about menstruation.

BCG's Laura Fox joined as a consultant in 2015. Previously, she spent five years in Qatar, Bangladesh and the US, in marketing, branding and digital strategy roles in consumer finance, museum, government and the NGO sectors. Fox earned her MBA in global strategy from NYU Stern, where she received the school’s Service Award for leadership and the Business & Society Program’s international post-MBA fellowship to China.
BCG's Jim Hemerling practices smart ways to deal with, and even grow from, the unavoidable and accelerating transformations taking place at work.
Oded Shoseyov’s researches plant molecular biology protein engineering and nanobiotechnology, creating super-performing materials that are could change the way we build our future products.

Uzbek pianist Naufal Mukumi started playing the piano at the age of seven and performed with the Symphonic Orchestra of Uzbekistan from the age of nine. At 16, he moved to England to study at the Purcell School and then won scholarships to study at the Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance. He won the Young Soloist Competition in 2013 and the soloists’ competition at Trinity Laban in 2015.

Min Zhu became the deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund in 2011. Prior to working at the IMF, Zhu was the deputy governor of the central bank in his native China. Zhu received a PhD and an MA in economics from Johns Hopkins University and an MPA from the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University.
Lisa Dyson thinks a new class of crops might help us reinvent agriculture -- and feed the world.

As the founder and CEO of Glowee, a Paris-based startup, Sandra Rey is betting on a future powered by bioluminescence. Rey has a master’s degree from the French design school Strate College and took social entrepreneurship courses at the business school ESCP Europe.
Sebastian Kraves wants to bring DNA science to more people in new places.
BCG's Leila Hoteit specializes in human capital and education throughout the Middle East.
BCG's Seema Bansal asks: Can governments actually make a meaningful difference in education? And rapidly? Yes, it turns out.
Neha Narula is helping redefine the future of money by researching cryptocurrencies and providing clarity on how digital currencies will transform our world.

BCG's Mike Schwartz is a partner, managing director and global chairman of the Blockchain Technologies Lab at the Sydney office of BCG Digital Ventures, an investment and incubation firm dedicated to supporting some of the world’s most influential and innovative startups. Before starting at BCG in 2002, Schwartz founded Genos, an organization working to improve emotional intelligence assessments and development tools in workplaces.

BCG's Lars Fæste is a Managing Director and Senior Partner and Global Leader of BCG’s Transformation practice.  He also serves as system leader of BCG Greater China. Fæste has extensive experience of large-scale transformations, often in connection with mergers and acquisitions. He has an engineering degree from the Danish Technical University in Copenhagen and an MBA from the Rotterdam School of Management in the Netherlands.

Award-winning beatboxer, producer and songwriter MaJiKer is a British musical polymath who currently lives in Paris. He has produced two platinum-selling albums and won three French Grammys, the BBC Radio 3 European Album of the Year, critics and press prizes at the Sanremo Song Festival and the French Mercury Music Prize. A prolific collaborator, he has worked with an eclectic range of international artists and created his own projects in the studio and onstage. He once beatboxed at the BBC Proms. MaJiKer is currently developing several new projects, including a solo sonata for beatbox and piano.
BCG's Olivier Scalabre analyzes the evolution of large industrial companies' manufacturing footprint and operations.
Michael Bodekaer is a serial entrepreneur with a passion for building innovative technology companies that have the potential to change the world.
Juno Mac campaigns for better working conditions for sex workers by fighting criminalization and supporting public education projects around issues relating to sex worker rights.

Marwa Al-Sabouni suggests that architecture played a crucial role in the slow unraveling of Syrian cities' social fabric, preparing the way for once-friendly groups to become enemies instead of neighbors.
Monica Araya works with leaders in government, business, philanthropy and activism to accelerate the shift toward emissions-free transportation.
Jennifer Brea was a PhD student at Harvard when, one night, she found she couldn't write her own name.

Hays and Ryan Holladay create innovative sonic experiences that blur the lines between art and technology. Their work celebrates the act of discovery, reimagining how we interact with and experience sound.
Joe Lassiter focuses on one of the world’s most pressing problems: developing clean, secure and carbon-neutral supplies of reliable, low-cost energy all around the world.
Isaac Lidsky has a very eclectic resume.

Emma Marris is a writer focusing on environmental science, policy and culture, with an approach that she paints as being "more interested in finding and describing solutions than delineating problems, and more interested in joy than despair."
Abigail Marsh asks essential questions: If humans are evil, why do we sometimes go to extraordinary lengths to help others even at a cost to ourselves?
As director of the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, Gerard Ryle is one of the key figures behind the Panama Papers.
Michael Shellenberger is a global thinker on energy, technology and the environment.
Suzanne Simard studies the complex, symbiotic networks in our forests.
Jonathan Tepperman writes on the world's most pervasive and seemingly intractable challenges.
Bettina Warburg is a blockchain researcher, entrepreneur and educator. A political scientist by training, she has a deep passion for the intersection of politics and technology.
University student Ione Wells is the founder of the international #NotGuilty campaign against sexual violence and misdirected victim blaming.
Professor Sajay Samuel's proposal to reduce the burden of student loans is part of his larger preoccupation with thinking beyond the conventional categories of economics and ecology.
Tristan Harris helps the technology industry more consciously and ethically shape the human spirit and human potential.
Elise Roy thinks that designers have the capacity and responsibility to address and resolve human problems on micro and macro scales and contribute to social well-being.
Gill Hicks has dedicated her life to being an advocate for peace.
Julia Galef investigates how and why people change their minds.
Dave Brain studies the plasma environments and atmospheres of unmagnetized planets.
Molly Winter works on legalizing sustainable building practices.
Timothy Ihrig advocates for an approach to healthcare that prioritizes a patient's personal values.
Gonzalo Vilariño uses sport to change the rules of the game for the disabled.
Dr. Christopher Bell specializes in the study of popular culture, focusing on the ways in which race, class and gender intersect in different forms of media.
Rainn Wilson is an actor ("The Office"), comedian and film producer, a climate advocate and a member of the advisory board of Arctic Basecamp.
David Camarillo's research focuses on understanding and preventing traumatic brain injury.
Water is the basis of life, and too many people around the world suffer from waterborne illnesses. Deepika Kurup is working to change that.
Laura Vanderkam shatters the myth that there just isn’t enough time in the week for working professionals to live happy, balanced and productive lives.

Katie Hinde is studying breast milk’s status as the first superfood, providing babies with invaluable microbes custom-tailored to their individual needs, via an incredible and unlikely dialogue between the mother’s enzymes and the baby’s saliva.
Kathy Nicholson Hull founded the first freestanding pediatric palliative care center in the US.
Stacy Smith shows how Hollywood’s homogenous (and overwhelmingly male) culture systematically excludes women and minorities.
As a pioneer in critical race theory, Kimberlé Crenshaw helped open the discussion of the double bind faced by victims of simultaneous racial and gender prejudice.

speaker_name: Alicia Garza, Patrisse Cullors and Opal Tometi
speaker_description: Alicia Garza launched a global movement with a single Facebook post that ended with the words: “Black lives matter.”
With a voice amplified by unthinkable personal tragedy, Suzanne Barakat speaks out against bigotry and violence against those society deems "different."
In her groundbreaking book Girls & Sex, Peggy Orenstein explores the changing landscape of modern sexual expectations and its troubling impact on adolescents and young women.

Brimming with insights gained on her picaresque journey from firefighter to best-selling author, Caroline Paul’s "The Gutsy Girl: Escapades for Your Life of Epic Adventure" is a revolutionary guide for raising brave young women.
Sisonke Msimang untangles the threads of race, class and gender that run through the fabric of African and global culture.

speaker_name: Tiq Milan and Kim Katrin Milan
speaker_description: Already a tireless advocate for positive and honest portrayals of LGBTQ people in media, Tiq Milan now evangelizes for the unifying power of love.
Nanfu Wang uncovers untold stories about human rights in China.
Miriam Zoila Pérez investigates how race and gender affect health -- and the people who create spaces for healing.
With scholarship and incisive commentary that exposes the marginalized narratives hidden within "mainstream" history, Brittney Cooper writes at the vanguard of cultural criticism.
Delivering pointedly frank observations with down-home sincerity, actor Ashley Judd is building a committed activist career on intense personal experience.
With an eye for nature’s forms and lessons learned from its materials, Jeanne Gang creates iconic environments that stand in curvy relief to blocky urban cityscapes.
Bringing cross-disciplinary tactics and innovation to a moribund defense industry, N Square’s Erika Gregory seeks to wean the world from its nuclear stockpiles.
Long revered in the UK for her wit and candor, Sandi Toksvig is now lending her familiar voice to a greater cause -- equality for women.
David Burkus challenges the traditional and widely accepted principles of business management.
Philippa Neave is senior advisor on the UN's Lexicon of Electoral Terminology.
Sayu Bhojwani recruits and supports first and second generation Americans to run for public office.
Former Marine and Yale Law School graduate J.D. Vance writes about how upward mobility really feels.
Rabbi Sharon Brous is a leading voice in reanimating religious life in America, working to develop a spiritual roadmap for soulful, multi-faith justice work.
Michele L. Sullivan is known for her sustainable and collaborative approach to philanthropic investing.
Jude Kelly is artistic director of Southbank Centre, Britain’s largest cultural institution.
Thordis Elva is one of the two authors of "South of Forgiveness," a unique collaboration between a survivor and perpetrator of rape.

Can we use trade to fight terrorism?  Romaine Seguin believes that when communities are isolated from the global economy, they risk becoming breeding grounds for terrorist groups -- and trade may be a way to ward off this isolation. Seguin illuminates home grown global businesses, like the Haiti-based Deux Mains, which can provide the jobs and security that are the most impactful tools of humanitarian aid.

Katie Francfort works on retail and healthcare strategy for UPS. In her role as a specialty pharmaceuticals marketing manager, she works with pharmaceutical companies that manufacture and donate products for humanitarian aid.
UPS's Wanis Kabbaj seeks new ways of understanding the growing complexity of our congested cities and globalized world.

Jenna Schilstra grew up in a country divided between two languages: Dutch and French-speaking Belgium. A childhood steeped in languages seeded a lifelong yearning to overcome language barriers and communicate with the unfamiliar. As a customer technology manager on UPS’s mobile strategy team, Schilstra's international perspective has informed the expansion of the company’s mobile presence to 83 countries.

Amelia Laytham is a marketing manager at UPS, where she develops and executes strategies for revenue growth in Baltimore, Philadelphia and Washington, D.C. Laytham transitioned into the marketing department after being an industrial engineer with UPS for 11 years.

As the director of healthcare marketing and strategy for UPS, Jan Denecker executes healthcare strategy in Europe. He finds new ways to help healthcare companies cope with the medical industry’s growing need for agile and flexible supply chains. Prior to joining UPS in 2011, Denecker worked in the healthcare industry for more than 10 years, where he focused on marketing and global supply chains.

As curator of mammals at Zoo Atlanta, Stephanie Braccini Slade can attest that animals, just like humans, need to make choices to feel in control of their lives. Slade shares the story of a troubled chimpanzee named Holly to explain how crafting opportunities for choice in an animal’s environment can create positive behavioral outcomes and improve their overall quality of life. “I’m not an expert on humans,” Slade says, “but I think we can learn a lot from the animal world.”
Augie Picado is the country manager for UPS Mexico.

Monica Johnson is a manager of escheatment and unclaimed funds for UPS’s Corporate Tax Department, which means she connects abandoned funds to their rightful owner. As the founder of That Girl is S.M.A.R.T., a nonprofit that mentors young girls, she strives to help others reach their potential.

As the senior manager of integration and automation at Coyote Logistics, Mario Paluzzi oversees the development of technology that underpins a more efficient and connected world. Recently, he helped launch a mobile app for drivers and an online web portal for customers and carriers.
Kate Adams spends her days dissecting digital communications to find a better way to tell brand stories and connect with customers.
UPS's advanced analytics manager Mallory Freeman researches how to do the most good with data.

John Bidden’s musical training solidified within a Detroit church choir. In 1999, he began to lead worship services, and within a decade he was an ordained minister. Today, Bidden is an independent recording artist with a philosophical style that fuses contemporary Christian and gospel music. He has released two albums, “I Am Free” in 2012 and “Speak Life” in 2015.
Danny Dorling teaches and writes about the geography of our human world.

Dr. Musimbi Kanyoro is globally recognized for her leadership of organizations and initiatives that advance health, development, human rights and philanthropy for communities, specifically for women and girls.
Poet, playwright, filmmaker and educator Chinaka Hodge uses her own life and experiences as the backbone of wildly creative, powerful works.
Ryan Gravel is an architect and urban planner who played a key role in developing the Atlanta BeltLine.
Adam de la Zerda develops new medical imaging technologies to detect and destroy cancer.
Alyssa Monks transfers the intimacy and vulnerability of human experience onto a painted surface.
Trevor Copp is known for innovative social justice theater that blends physicality, image and narrative.
A former committed pioneer of violent jihad, Manwar Ali draws on his experience and deepening understanding of Islam to prevent radicalisation and extremism.
Tasos Frantzolas lives and creates at the intersection of audio and technology.
Ian Bremmer is the president and founder of Eurasia Group, a political risk research and consulting firm.
Kelli Jean Drinkwater is a multi-disciplinary artist and activist recognized for her creative practice and voice in radical body politics.
Kandice Sumner thinks we've been looking at the "achievement gap" in education all wrong.
Roger Antonsen combines science, mathematics and computer science with entertainment, philosophy and visualizations.
Fawn Qiu is a multi-disciplinary technologist who introduces the creative side of engineering through playful projects.
Adam Galinsky teaches people all over the world how to inspire others, speak up effectively, lead teams and negotiate successfully.
IBM's Caleb Barlow is focused on how we solve the cyber security problem by changing the economics for the bad guys.

Andrew Arruda is the CEO and co-founder of ROSS Intelligence, the world’s first artificially intelligent lawyer. ROSS reads millions of legal documents efficiently, understands lawyers’ research questions and gets smarter each time it interacts with a lawyer. Before he co-founded the company, Arruda worked at a litigation boutique in Toronto, Canada and with the Canadian department of foreign affairs, trade and development in Lisbon, Portugal.

Raised by an immigrant single mother in the projects of New York City, Villy Wang’s longing to tell her mom’s story forged a passion for media because of its power to share and shape narratives. So she founded BAYCAT, a social enterprise in San Francisco that helps young people from low-income communities capture untold stories and create social change. After 10 years, BAYCAT has educated close to 4,000 students; their recent graduates have gone on to work at Netflix, Lucasfilm, Pixar, HBO, Universal Studios and other production companies.

Ise Lyfe is a spoken word artist and performer, educator, community organizer and activist from Oakland, California. His conceptual art project, Brighter Than Blight, transformed a blighted condemned housing project into a life-sized exhibition and artistic narrative on housing as a human right. His one-man show based on his book, "Pistols and Prayers," addresses American apathy and resilience through the lens of the generation born into the crack epidemic.
IBM's George Tulevski wants to use carbon nanotubes to revolutionize microchip design.

Dr. Laxmi Parida is a distinguished research staff member in computational genomics at IBM and a visiting professor at New York University’s Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences. In her work, she applies highly abstract mathematical and computational models to answer urgent human needs, like finding viable food supply chains and personalizing cancer medicine.

Wobbly World is a group of internationally recognized musicians and singers from an ever-expanding list of countries: Morocco, the Netherlands, Bolivia, Lebanon, Cuba, Vietnam, Ivory Coast, Palestine, Trinidad and the U.S. Founded by guitarist Freddy Clarke, the music ethno-layers melody, poetry and meaning from disparate musical traditions. Yet despite this diversity, the music soars with a deep sense of cohesion. Wobbly World is built on the idea that the unity of music speaks to the unity of life, and that the freedom to enjoy music without borders leads us to enjoy people without borders.

Dr. Bob Nease’s recent book, "The Power of Fifty Bits: The New Science of Turning Good Intentions into Positive Results," offers practical strategies to help people improve their behavior. Before becoming a writer, Nease was the chief scientist at Express Scripts, where he researched how behavioral science could improve health care. Under his leadership, the company developed strategies that improved decisions while preserving choice for millions of patients.

Dr. James Kozloski manages IBM’s Computational Neuroscience & Multiscale Brain Modeling department. His research reframes the brain as a single circuit, potentially reshaping how we find and treat brain diseases. But the possible impact of Kozloski’s work stretches far beyond healthcare: further demystification of the brain will inform the future of computing through the brain-inspired software that electronics are increasingly built upon.
IBM's Grady Booch is shaping the future of cognitive computing by building intelligent systems that can reason and learn.

When she was only 20 years old, Juliane Gallina became the first woman to serve as the United States Naval Academy’s (USNA) brigade commander. Today, she is a retired Navy leader with more than two decades of service. As IBM’s director of Cognitive Solutions for National Security, she utilizes that expertise to adapt cognitive technology for security purposes
IBM's Charity Wayua is a research manager in Nairobi, Kenya, where she leads the company's public sector research team.
Motivated by his wife's bout with cancer, IBM's Joshua Smith applies his engineering expertise to early diagnosis.
Natalie Panek's work is focused on the idea that accountability for our environments never goes away.
Carolyn Jones creates projects that point our attention towards issues of global concern.
Emtithal "Emi" Mahmoud dedicates her time to spreading understanding through poetry and advocacy, particularly for the cause of refugees and disadvantaged communities the world over.
Sue Klebold has become a passionate agent working to advance mental health awareness and intervention.
Lloyd Pendleton wants to eliminate chronic homelessness.
Sharon Terry is developing ways for ordinary people to transform biomedical research and healthcare.
Caitlin Doughty asks: What if we re-designed the funeral industry for an eco-friendly end of life?
Lucy Kalanithi is dedicated to helping others choose the health care and end-of-life experiences that best align with their values.
Jennifer Pluznick is on a mission to find out more about olfactory and other sensory receptors.
David Casarett asks: What if mainstream health care operated more like a medical marijuana dispensary?
David R. Williams asks: What if we decided to tackle the striking levels of early death and poor health that are due to the color of one's skin?
Anjan Chatterjee seeks to answer a tantalizing question: Why is beauty so gripping?
Ashton Cofer and his FIRST Robotics team won the Google Science Fair for developing a process to convert Styrofoam waste into activated carbon for purifying water.
A billion people around the world lack access to health care because they live too far from a clinic. 2017 TED Prize winner Raj Panjabi aims to extend health services to the last mile.
Jia Jiang's journey through rejection revealed a world hidden in plain sight, where people are much kinder than we imagine.
Veerle Provoost studies genetic and social parenthood in the context of donor conception.
Kevin B. Jones is a life-long student of human nature, fascinated most by the decision-making capacity intrinsic to each of us.
TED Fellow Dr. Rebecca Brachman is a pioneer in the field of preventative psychopharmacology, developing drugs to enhance stress resilience and prevent mental illness.
Paul Knoepfler is a biomedical scientist and writer focusing on stem cells and genetics.
Jeff Kirschner created a global community that's eradicating litter one piece at a time.
Susan Robinson is a business leader, inspirational speaker, blogger, entrepreneur and TED Resident. And she is legally blind.
TED Resident Hadi Eldebek is a musician, educator and entrepreneur who creates artistic, cultural, and educational projects around the world.
Zubaida Bai innovates health and livelihood solutions for underserved women and girls around the world.
Marlon Peterson is a writer, youth development expert and human justice advocate.
James Beacham is an experimental high-energy particle physicist working with the ATLAS collaboration at CERN's Large Hadron Collider.
Chetna Gala Sinha is the founder and chair of the Mann Deshi Bank, aimed at the needs of rural women micro-entrepreneurs in India.
David Autor's work assesses the labor market consequences of technological change and globalization.
Anjali Tripathi explores planets to uncover the processes that make and destroy them.
Sofia Jawed-Wessel's teachings utilize a sex-positive and pleasure-inclusive approach to providing medically accurate, comprehensive sexuality education.
Deeyah Khan is working to create intercultural dialogue and understanding by confronting the world's most complex and controversial topics.
Alejandro Sánchez Alvarado wants to understand the how and why of tissue regeneration.
Dan Bricklin helped fuel the rapid growth of the personal computer industry.
Emily Parsons-Lord makes cross-disciplinary contemporary art that is informed by research and critical dialogue with materials and climate science.
Robb Willer's political research has investigated various topics, including economic inequality, racial prejudice, masculine overcompensation and Americans' views of climate change.
Alan Smith uses interactive graphics and statistics to breathe new life into how data is presented.
Lara Setrakian is building innovative news platforms that stand ready to engage and explain the complexity of our world.
Lux Narayan is a perpetual learner of various things -- from origami and molecular gastronomy to stand-up and improv comedy.
Todd Scott uses humor and pop culture to make CPR training more memorable.
Ashton Applewhite asks us to look at ageism -- the assumption that older people are alike and that aging impoverishes us.

Salil Dudani has experienced the legal system from two vantage points: being detained by D.C. police on suspicion of "terrorist activity," and working as an investigator with civil rights lawyers challenging poverty-jailing.
Nagin Cox explores Mars as part of the team that operates NASA's rovers.
Eduardo Briceño is a learner, leader, speaker and writer devoted to enabling a more learning-oriented world.
Aala El-Khani explores the needs of families affected by war and displacement and the mental health of children who have experienced armed conflict.
Amy Adele Hasinoff studies gender, sexuality, privacy and consent in new media.
Margaret Bourdeaux investigates the best ways to protect, recover and reconstruct health systems and institutions disrupted by war or disaster.
Jonathan Rossiter develops soft robotic technologies and turns them into real robots and smart machines for engineers, musicians, doctors and artists.
Mona Chalabi tries to take the numb out of numbers. She's left with lots of "ers."
Amy Green creates narrative video games that focus on innovative stories.
A former member of Westboro Baptist Church, Megan Phelps-Roper is now a writer and educator on topics related to extremism, bullying and empathy in dialogue.
Karina Galperin studies the culture, language and literature of early modern Iberia.

As Director of National Drug Control Policy, Michael Botticelli led the Obama Administration’s drug policy efforts to diminish the consequences of substance use through evidence-based prevention, treatment and recovery support services.
Nabila Alibhai leads inCOMMONS, a new cultural production lab focused on invigorating public spaces and inspiring collective responsibility for our cultural and environmental heritage.
Birder and ecologist Washington Wachira started the Youth Conservation Awareness Programme to nurture young environmental enthusiasts in Kenya.
Christian Benimana wants to develop the talent and potential of the next generation of African designers with socially-focused design principles.
Sitawa Wafula started Kenya's first free mental health and epilepsy support line.
A pioneering graphic designer in Egypt, Ghada Wali has designed fonts, brands and design-driven art projects.
With a background as an acrobat and dancer, Qudus Onikeku is one of the preeminent Nigerian choreographers working today.
Writing on urban development, sexual and reproductive rights, gender and queerness, OluTimehin Adegbeye resists marginalization by reminding her audiences of the validity of every human experience.
Stephanie Busari is a journalist and editor at CNN International Digital.
Ani Liu explores the intersection between technology and sensory perception.

TED Fellow Anab Jain imagines and builds future worlds we can experience in the present moment. By creating new ways of seeing, being and acting, she inspires and challenges us to look critically at the decisions and choices we make today.
How can the "inner universe" of consciousness be explained in terms of mere biology and physics? Anil Seth explores the brain basis of consciousness and self.
Anna Heringer’s sustainable designs lend breathtaking forms to easily-available local materials while developing the skills and consciousness of their builders.
With disarming familiarity, Anne Lamott tackles what most don’t like to consider. Her honest writing helps us make sense of life’s chaos.

Whether brewing better beer, discovering novel antibiotics or chronicling the lives of the microscopic creatures living in the dust under the couch, Anne Madden seeks to understand and utilize the microbial world around us.
Anika Paulson’s love for music permeates her understanding of herself, her surroundings and the mysteries that make up the smallest and biggest parts of life.
Gabriela González is part of the collaboration of more than 1,000 scientists who measured for the first time the gravitational waves that Einstein predicted over 100 years ago.

Ingrid Betancourt was a presidential candidate in Colombia in 2002 when she was kidnapped by guerilla rebels. After six years in captivity and a high-profile rescue, she now writes about what she learned about fear, forgiveness and the divine.
In his videos and performances, Jacob Collier sings every part, plays every instrument and visualizes every component with a captivating vision.
Jorge Drexler is a musician and the first Uruguayan to win an Oscar. His music plays with genre and influence, combining subtle harmonies and regional styles with electronic effects.
Inspired by classic city simulation games, Finnish designer Karoliina Korppoo and her fellow game developers at Colossal Order are infusing a venerable gaming genre with fresh perspectives.
Through her fiction, Lisa Genova beckons us into the lives of people with neurological disease, making their worlds real and relatable.
Luma Mufleh does something revolutionary: she coaches soccer. A Jordanian immigrant and Muslim of Syrian descent, Mufleh is determined to empower refugee children everywhere.
Rabbi Lord Jonathan Sacks exercised a primary influence on the thought and philosophy of people of all faiths worldwide.
Taking cues from bottom-up biological networks like those of social insects, Radhika Nagpal helped design an unprecedented “swarm” of ant-like robots.
Inspired by Mister Rogers, Sara DeWitt strives to make every child feel special by charting the forefront of new digital mediums where kids spend their time.
Susan Pinker reveals how in-person social interactions are not only necessary for human happiness but also could be a key to health and longevity.
Carrie Poppy tells stories on the fringes of human experience through writing, live storytelling and radio.
Gretchen Carlson is a tireless advocate for workplace equality and women's empowerment.
Joy Buolamwini's research explores the intersection of social impact technology and inclusion.
Anna Rosling Rönnlund's personal mission: to make it easy for anyone to understand the world visually.

Elizabeth Blackburn won a Nobel Prize for her pioneering work on telomeres and telomerase, which may play central roles in how we age. She is president of the Salk Institute and author of the New York Times Best Seller, "The Telomere Effect."
Helen Pearson's book, "The Life Project," tells the extraordinary story of the longest-running study of human development in the world.
Climate scientist Kate Marvel looks at the big picture of environmental change.
Laura Galante profiles advanced cyber threats and network breaches and investigates the political, military and financial implications of cyber operations.
Martin Ford imagines what the accelerating progress in robotics and artificial intelligence may mean for the economy, job market and society of the future.
Through his writing and his realized projects, Peter Calthorpe has spread the vision of New Urbanism, a framework for creating sustainable, human-scaled places.
Jorge Ramos's work covers the issues that affect the 55 million Latinos in the United States and immigrants all over the world.
With his futuristic artworks, Daan Roosegaarde illuminates the intersection of technology, humanity and our urban environments.
Data skeptic Cathy O’Neil uncovers the dark secrets of big data, showing how our "objective" algorithms could in fact reinforce human bias.
Garry Kasparov is esteemed by many as the greatest chess player of all time. Now he’s engaged in a game with far higher stakes: the preservation of democracy.
David Brenner is developing a unique type of light to kill viruses safely.
At FoodLab Detroit, Devita Davison supports local entrepreneurs and imagines a new future for food justice.

In her book "The Power of Meaning," Emily Esfahani Smith rounds up the latest research --_x000D_
 and the stories of fascinating people she interviewed -- to argue that the search for meaning is far more fulfilling than the pursuit of personal happiness.
As a child, Huang Yi longed for a robot companion. As an adult, he created a robot to dance with: KUKA.
Titus Kaphar's artworks interact with the history of art by appropriating its styles and mediums.
With her legendary spirit and unstoppable serve, tennis legend Serena Williams has become one of the world’s most enduring athletic superstars.
Tomás Saraceno invites us to consider the impossible, like spiders that play music or cities in the sky.
As co-creator of Siri, Tom Gruber helped redefine the role of machine intelligence in our lives and transformed the way we interact with our devices.
Anthony D. Romero is the executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU).
Ray Dalio is the founder, chair and co-chief investment officer of Bridgewater Associates, a global leader in institutional portfolio management and the largest hedge fund in the world.

speaker_name: T. Morgan Dixon and Vanessa Garrison
speaker_description: T. Morgan Dixon is the cofounder and CEO of GirlTrek, inspiring more than 100,000 neighborhood walkers.
OK Go fearlessly dream and build new worlds in a time when creative boundaries have all but dissolved.
Justin Davidson writes about a broad range of urban, civic, design and arts issues.
Françoise Mouly is The New Yorker's longtime art editor.
Sinéad Burke amplifies voices and instigates curious conversations.
Giorgia Lupi sees beauty in data. She challenges the impersonality that data communicate, designing engaging visual narratives that re-connect numbers to what they stand for: stories, people, ideas.
Siamak Hariri holds deep respect for the transformative potential of architecture, specializing in creating works of enduring value.
Michael Bierut is a partner in the New York office of Pentagram, a founder of Design Observer and a teacher at Yale School of Art and Yale School of Management.
Does humanity have a future as uploaded minds? In his work, Robin Hanson asks this and other extra-large questions.
David Whyte writes at the intersection of interior and exterior worlds, what he calls the conversational nature of reality, bringing new territory into view with his distinctly personal style.
Could an AI pass the entrance exam for the University of Tokyo? Noriko Arai oversees a project that wants to find out.
At iCarbonX, Jun Wang aims to establish a big data platform for health management.
Grace H. Kim is an internationally recognized expert in cohousing -- the art and craft of creating communities.
Rutger Bregman is the author of "Utopia for Realists."
Scientist and retired Navy officer Dr. David Titley asks a big question: Could the US military play a role in combating climate change?
As president of the International Rescue Committee, David Miliband enlists his expert statesmanship in the fight against the greatest global refugee crisis since World War II.
Jim Yong Kim is leading a global effort to end extreme poverty and promote shared prosperity.
Ted Halstead breathed new life into US and global climate policy by mobilizing conservative leaders and CEOs around a breakthrough carbon dividends solution.
Mehdi Ordikhani-Seyedlar is a machine learning engineer using data mining techniques on large-scale data.
Jon Boogz is a movement artist, choreographer and director who seeks to push the evolution of dance.
Marc Raibert is the founder and CEO of robot maker Boston Dynamics.
John Koenig is writing an original dictionary of made-up words.
With a fan following that runs into multi-millions, Shah Rukh Khan is at forefront of the Indian film industry and continues to rule at the box office in India.

Dr. Peter Weinstock is an Intensive Care Unit physician and Director of the Pediatric Simulator Program at Boston Children's Hospital/Harvard Medical School. Peter and his team fuse medicine with state of the art special effects, puppeteering and 3D printing technologies to create lifelike simulations of complex surgeries.
Dan Bell films urban decay.
Stuart Russell wrote the standard text on AI; now he thinks deeply on AI's future -- and the future of us humans, too.
With his membership platform Patreon, YouTube star Jack Conte may have solved a perennial problem of content creators -- getting paid for digital media.
Kristin Poinar uses remote sensing and numerical models to study the interaction of meltwater with ice flow, especially on the Greenland Ice Sheet.

Tim Kruger researches geoengineering: techniques to counteract climate change by deliberate, large-scale intervention in the earth system -- either by reflecting sunlight back into space or by reducing the level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
Joseph Redmon works on the YOLO algorithm, which combines the simple face detection of your phone camera with a cloud-based AI -- in real time.
Laolu Senbanjo's motto is: “Everything is my canvas.”
As the host of the "TED Radio Hour," Manoush Zomorodi explores fascinating ideas, astonishing inventions and new ways to think and create with the world's most remarkable minds.
With his "Microsculpture" series, Levon Biss photographs the incredible details of insects.
Moshe Szyf's research is focused on understanding the broad implications of epigenetic mechanisms in human behavior, health and disease.
Chuck Nice is a radio and TV veteran with a passion for science communication and comedy.
Katie Bouman is part of an international team of astronomers that's creating the world's largest telescope to take the very first picture of a black hole.
Casey Brown wants people to be paid well for their excellence.
Ari Wallach helps leaders more consciously and ethically shape tomorrow.
Sebastián Bortnik's work is focused on preventing cyber attacks.
Jonathan Marks works at the intersections of ethics, law and policy -- writing and speaking about torture, obesity, fracking, health care and other pressing issues of our time.
Richard Browning is the founder of human propulsion technology startup Gravity, which has invented, built and patented a personal flight system.
Natasha Hurley-Walker uses novel radio telescopes to explore the universe at some of the longest wavelengths of light.
Curtis “Wall Street” Carroll overcame poverty, illiteracy, incarceration and a lack of outside support to become a stock investor, creator and teacher of his own financial literacy philosophy.

Siddhartha Roy is an environmental engineer and research scientist, who works at the nexus of drinking water, public health and environmental justice. He and his team helped uncover the Flint, Michigan Water Crisis.
Carina Morillo is an advocate for the social inclusion of people with autism.
Pope Francis is the head of the Roman Catholic Church and a strong advocate of global action against climate change, to which he has devoted his powerful 2015 encyclical "Laudato Si'."
Dr. Anita Collins is an educator, researcher and writer in the field of brain development and music learning.
TED Fellow Mei Lin Neo is helping giant clams step out of their shells and show the world that they can be the heroes of the oceans, too.
Karim Abouelnaga is working to provide kids with access to high-quality academic summer programming.
TED Fellow Christopher Ategeka is on a mission to ensure a sustainable future for humanity and the planet.
TED Fellow Damon Davis makes art to empower the disenfranchised and combat oppression.
TED Fellow Matilda Ho is shaping the startup landscape to create more sustainable food systems in China.
TED Fellow Prumsodun Ok heals, empowers and advocates using the ancient art of Khmer classical dance.
TED Fellow Kayla Briët explores themes of identity and self-discovery in multiple mediums of storytelling: film, multi-media arts and music.

TED Fellow Lauren Sallan is a "next generation" paleobiologist applying cutting-edge developments in big data analytics to reveal how evolution happens at the largest scales (macroevolution), particularly in the oceans.
TED Fellow Dr. Elizabeth Wayne is a biomedical engineer and advocate for women in higher education.

TED Fellow Anjan Sundaram has spent the last decade writing about 21st century dictatorships, forgotten conflicts and discrimination around the world – from the Democratic Republic of Congo to Rwanda and India.
Wanuri Kahiu wants to curate, commission and create art that celebrates fun, fierce and frivolous Africa.
TED Fellow Armando Azua-Bustos studies how microbial life has adapted to survive in the Atacama Desert, the driest place on Earth.
Deborah Lipstadt's research focuses on the development of Holocaust denial and how to fight for the truth in an era marked by "alternative facts."
Kate Stafford's research examines migratory movements, geographic variation and physical drivers of marine mammals, particularly large whales.
Triona McGrath researches how the oceans are changing due to human activities.
Wendy Troxel specializes in behavioral treatments for insomnia and other sleep disorders.
Nina Fedoroff writes and lectures about the history and science of genetically modified organisms.
Anindya Kundu suggests all students can succeed if provided collective support systems and opportunities.
Nikki Webber Allen is working to create a safe space for honest conversations about mental health in communities of color.
TED Resident Paul Tasner is the co-founder and CEO of PulpWorks, Inc., designers and manufacturers of biodegradable packaging for consumer goods.
Duarte Geraldino is working on a multi-year project that chronicles the lives of citizens who lose people to deportation.
TED Resident Jackson Bird is using digital storytelling to demystify the transgender experience.
TED Resident Beth Malone brings bold art to public spaces across the US, encouraging artists to have a sense of humor, to be vulnerable and take creative risks.
TED Resident Sue Jaye Johnson explores the ways cultural expectations shape our public and private behavior.
TED Resident Dan Gartenberg has spent his adult life trying to make seven and a half hours feel like eight hours.
TED Resident Carlos Bautista wants to close the information and technology gap for people in developing countries.
Cheyenne Cochrane is an ambassador for the natural hair movement.
Katrina Spade created a system called "recomposition" that transforms human bodies into soil, so that we can return to the earth after we die.
Liz Hajek studies sedimentary rocks to understand how landscapes change and evolve.
With astronaut eyes and ethnographer curiosity, Tricia Wang helps corporations grow by discovering the unknown about their customers.
Zachariah Mampilly is an expert on the politics of both violent and non-violent resistance.
Vivek Maru is the founder of Namati, a movement for legal empowerment around the world powered by cadres of grassroots legal advocates.
To showcase vital new art from African nations and the diaspora, Touria El Glaoui founded the powerhouse 1-54 Contemporary African Art Fair.
Tania Douglas imagined how biomedical engineering could help address some of Africa's health challenges.
Sethembile Msezane deconstructs the act of public commemoration -- how it creates myths, constructs histories, includes some and excludes others.

Sara Menker is founder and CEO of Gro Intelligence, a tech company that marries the application of machine learning with domain expertise and enables users to understand and predict global food and agriculture markets.
Pierre Thiam shares the cuisine of his home in Senegal through global restaurants and highly praised cookbooks.
Nnedi Okorafor weaves African cultures into the evocative settings and memorable characters of her science fiction work for kids and adults.
Ndidi Okonkwo Nwuneli is an expert on social innovation, African agriculture and nutrition, entrepreneurship and youth development.
Leo Igwe works to end a variety of human rights violations that are rooted in superstition, including witchcraft accusations, anti-gay hate, caste discrimination and ritual killing.

Christine Thach grew up in a culture of shared value. The daughter of a Cambodian refugee, a sense of collectivism threaded itself throughout the community that raised her. She now applies this style of thinking to her work, where she finds ways to add value to the customer and company in tandem.
UPS’s David Lee works to create platforms that make it easier for people to turn fuzzy ideas into concrete solutions.

For Jeff Kozak’s first assignment in the Air Force, he flew strategic airlifts during Desert Storm, transporting everything from troops to vehicles to munitions. Maximizing fuel efficiencies for the long flight legs between Europe and the Middle East was essential for success. His abilities to plan, execute and be precise were fine-tuned during his time as a pilot transporting United States leadership. Today, he continues to move fuel part-time into contested environments. He spends the rest of his working life at UPS, where he applies his expertise to implementing a new fueling strategy.

At UPS, Jennifer Allison designs applications that allow customers to complete complex tasks that feel simple. Inspired by her personal experiences, she leads her UX team with a rare philosophy: designing solutions for disabled users will ultimately improve the experience for all customers. A user interface designer by day, by night she's an avid painter and has published several coloring books.

Since joining UPS Freight in 2005, John McKown has driven more than two million accident-free miles. He is proud to share his knowledge about highway safety with the nation’s youth as a Road Team Captain, a title bestowed on a select group of exemplary drivers by the American Trucking Association. His experience on the road has also made him aware of the devastating problem of human trafficking on America’s highways—and has made him an ally in the fight to stop it.
UPS's Jon Bowers oversees driver and delivery training at one of the company's next-generation training facilities.
UPS's Julio Gil thinks that technology is flipping the equation on future cities, and that rural may soon become the new urban.
Mike Kinney plays a crucial role in helping customers reach their full potential.

Growing up in China while its youth culture was transforming, then living in the US and Germany, Sebastian Guo has witnessed a diversity of burgeoning millennial cultures. He began his UPS career in Atlanta as an international marketing intern, identifying opportunities in markets around the world. Now he works in Singapore, where he develops marketing analytics and infrastructure to drive revenue growth across 14 Asian markets.

As the director of urban innovation and mobility, Thomas Madrecki leads partnerships between UPS and city leaders to reduce congestion, increase quality of life and shape policy. Madrecki was a strategic communications manager before he took this position, and was overseeing public relations with a focus on federal policy in transportation and sustainability.

Uma Adwani is a billing supervisor at UPS’s global service center in Pune, India. She grew up a math-hater in a small town in India, at one point proposing that she was allergic to numbers. But this all changed when she was assigned to teach math as a primary school teacher in the Indian metropolis of Pune. She discovered something magical in multiplication tables, and her love story with math began.
Kym Loren Worthy is the prosecutor of Wayne County, Michigan, home to Detroit.
At Gearbox, Kamau Gachigi empowers Kenya's next generation of creators to prototype and fabricate their visions.
TED Fellow Joel Jackson is the founder and CEO of Mobius Motors, set to launch a durable, low-cost SUV made in Africa.
The work of Nigerian-born Iké Udé explores a world of dualities: photographer/performance artist, artist/spectator, African/post-nationalist, mainstream/marginal, individual/everyman and fashion/art.
Gus Casely-Hayford writes, lectures, curates and broadcasts about African culture.
DK Osseo-Asare creates architecture with and for the people that design overlooks.
Fredros Okumu studies human-mosquito interactions, hoping to better understand how to keep people from getting malaria.
Drawing on a rich cultural and personal history, Olúfẹ́mi Táíwò studies philosophy of law, social and political philosophy, Marxism, and African and Africana philosophy.
Best known f­or his exploration photography, George Steinmetz has a restless curiosity for the unknown: remote deserts, obscure cultures and the ­mysteries of science and technology.
Working across disciplines, Chika Ezeanya-Esiobu explores homegrown and grassroots approaches to the sustainable advancement of Sub-Saharan Africa.
Iyad Rahwan's work lies at the intersection of the computer and social sciences, with a focus on collective intelligence, large-scale cooperation and the social aspects of artificial intelligence.

Chris Sheldrick is providing a precise and simple way to talk about location, by dividing the world into a grid of three-meter by three-meter squares and assigning each one a unique three-word address.
Thandiswa Mazwai is one of the most influential South African musicians of this generation.
As an entrepreneur and investor in film, media and technology, Dayo Ogunyemi reconstructs the image and reality of Africa.

Kola Masha is the founder of Babban Gona, the first for-profit social enterprise in history to be awarded the prestigious Skoll Award, due to its financial sustainability and highly scalable impact. The organization is part-owned by the farmers they serve.
Kevin Njabo is coordinating the development of UCLA's newly established Congo Basin Institute (CBI) in Yaoundé, Cameroon.
Amar Inamdar works with businesses and entrepreneurs to imagine, create and grow markets that address our biggest social and environmental challenges.
Ronald Sullivan is a leading theorist in the areas of criminal law, criminal procedure, trial practice and techniques, legal ethics and race theory.

Alexander Wagner balances two passions: the thrill of seeking knowledge about fundamentals of human behavior for knowledge's sake, and the desire to apply insights in the real world and to improve the workings of markets and organizations.
Richard J. Berry is the mayor of Albuquerque -- the 32nd largest city in America and the largest city in New Mexico.
Niki Okuk is working to create social and economic justice and worker dignity.
Tara Winkler helps vulnerable children escape poverty and be cared for within their families.
David Baron writes about science in books, magazines, newspapers and for public radio. He formerly served as science correspondent for NPR and science editor for PRI’s The World.
Professor Carolyn Bertozzi is a chemical biologist who invents technologies and medicines based on disease-causing sugar molecules.
Through his mesmerizing satellite photographs, Benjamin Grant offers us a new way of seeing of our planet and ourselves.
Chance Coughenour is recreating heritage and culture that's been lost throughout the world.
Magatte Wade creates jobs in Africa -- and calls attention to the obstacles to job creation on the continent.
Through exploratory and human-centered research, Niti Bhan discovers and makes tangible pragmatic opportunities for sustainable and inclusive value creation.
Dr. Erin Marie Saltman manages Facebook's counterterrorism and counter-extremism policy work for Europe, the Middle East and Africa.
Dr. Helen Czerski investigates the physics of ocean bubbles and spends a lot of time sharing the big scientific ideas hidden in the small objects around us.
Chetan Bhatt teaches and writes about the numerous dangers human rights face today from resurgent Far Right movements.
Jennifer Granick fights for civil liberties in the age of surveillance and powerful digital technology.
Kasiva Mutua is working to elevate the place of the African woman in music.
TED Senior Fellow Edsel Salvana is studying the genetics of HIV, developing an affordable test for HIV drug resistance and fighting the spread of misinformation around vaccines and immunization.
Adong Judith uses art as a vehicle to drive social change and trains aspiring makers to create art that dares to ask serious questions.
TED Fellow Mike Gil conducts field experiments and builds mathematical models to understand how marine ecosystems function.

TED Fellow Nighat Dad heads the Digital Rights Foundation, Pakistan -- a researched based advocacy not-for-profit geared towards ICT to support human rights, democratic processes, and digital governance.
TED Fellow Pratik Shah creates novel intersections between engineering, medical imaging, machine learning and medicine.
Mennat El Ghalid research aims to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying fungal biology and pathogenicity.
TED Fellow Carl Joshua Ncube is one of Zimbabwe's best-known comedians.
TED Fellow Susan Emmett studies global hearing health disparities in 15 countries and Indigenous groups around the world, in an effort to fight preventable hearing loss.

TED Fellow Robert Hakiza is the co-founder of the Young African Refugees for Integral Development (YARID), which empowers refugees and builds community through vocational education, English classes, access to sports and computer literacy skills.
Marc Bamuthi Joseph investigates cultural erasure through performances that range from opera to dance theater.
TED Fellow Miho Janvier studies the the Sun -- in particular the origin of phenomena called "solar storms" which can impact planets in the solar system.
Katlego Kolanyane-Kesupile is the founder of the Queer Shorts Showcase Festival, Botswana's first and only LGBT-themed theatre festival.
TED Fellow Soyapi Mumba creates technology solutions for low-resource environments.
TED Fellow Walé Oyéjidé combats bias with creative storytelling.
TED Fellow Su Kahumbu is working to improve farmer livelihoods and contribute to nutritional security and environmental sustainability.
Sauti Sol blends warm resonant pop with traditional Kenyan influences. Their mélange of energetic rhythms has promoted the group to become one of Africa’s most celebrated.
Pete Ouko champions access to justice for inmates and the indolent in Africa.

speaker_name: Deb Willis and Hank Willis Thomas
speaker_description: Deb Willis is a photographer and writer in search of beauty.
Azim Khamisa speaks to students and adults on nonviolence, forgiveness and peace-building, and he is a founder of two nonprofit organizations that target youth violence.
Dixon Chibanda is passionate about the human brain, how it influences our behavior and what we can do to make everybody happy.
Joan Blades shares a simple six-person conversation guide that helps people with differences get to know and even like each other.
Eve Abrams makes radio stories, mostly about her adopted hometown, New Orleans.

speaker_name: Tiffany Kagure Mugo and Siphumeze Khundayi
speaker_description: The curator of HOLAAfrica, Tiffany Kagure Mugo is a wine bar philosopher who pontificates on all things and is willing to learn about everything else.
Theo E.J. Wilson encourages us to break through the divides that separate us.
Nancy Rabalais has studied coastal marine ecosystems for more than 40 years now and loves to share that knowledge.
Liz Ogbu is a global expert on engaging and transforming unjust urban environments.

speaker_occupation: Criminal and social justice reform advocate
speaker_description: At Clean Start Kenya, Teresa Njoroge builds bridges connecting the formerly imprisoned to the outside world and vice versa.
In her work, Clemantine Wamariya is learning and sharing how remembering our life experiences in story form guides us to make sense and appreciate our present moments.
Anjali Kumar is a Brooklyn-born, first-generation Indian American author, attorney, advisor, speaker and “idea acupuncturist.”
Felice Belle consumes and creates stories to make sense of the world and her place in it. She spends her free time solving fictional crimes.
An architect by training, John Cary has devoted his career to expanding the practice of design for the public good.
Wendy Suzuki is researching the science behind the extraordinary, life-changing effects that physical activity can have on the most important organ in your body: your brain.
A record-setting triathlete, Minda Dentler is a polio survivor committed to inspiring people to move beyond their fear of failure and achieve their goals.
Tara Houska is an attorney who fights for indigenous rights and justice.
Priya Vulchi is a co-founder of CHOOSE and author of "Tell Me Who You Are" (Penguin Random House, June 2019). She will graduate from Princeton University in 2022.
Shameem Akhtar is a teacher working to empower girls in Sindh, a province in the southeast of  Pakistan.
The co-founder of Proximie, Nadine Hachach-Haram is a curious surgeon with a passion for technology and innovation -- and a desire to make a difference in the world.
Deanna Van Buren is an architect who designs spaces for peacemaking, inside and out.

Harvard Medical School psychologist Susan David studies emotional agility: the psychology of how we can use emotion to bring forward our best selves in all aspects of how we love, live, parent and lead.
Lera Boroditsky is trying to figure out how humans get so smart.
Cleo Wade creates uplifting messages, blending simplicity with positivity and arresting honesty.
An outspoken feminist, Justin Baldoni has been doubling down on his efforts to start a dialogue with men to redefine masculinity.

Valarie Kaur is a social justice activist, lawyer, filmmaker, innovator, mother and Sikh American thought leader who founded the Revolutionary Love Project -- a movement that envisions a world where love is a public ethic.
Naomi McDougall Jones is a vocal advocate and activist for bringing gender parity to film, both on and off screen.

Karen Lloyd investigates novel types of microbes in Earth's deep surface biosphere, collecting them from remote places such as Arctic fjords, volcanoes in Costa Rica, even deep in mud near the Marianas Trench.
Wendy Woods is a Managing Director and Senior Partner of Boston Consulting Group (BCG) and Vice Chairman of BCG's Social Impact practice, which she helped create.
The author of "The Warmth of Other Suns," the story of the Great Migration, Isabel Wilkerson is a Pulitzer-winning journalist who uses narrative history to bring to light our shared humanity.
Euna Lee strives to be a voice for the voiceless and a window for those with no access to outside information.
Jazz-based cellist, singer, composer and improviser Helen Gillet performs her own eclectic mix of French, contemporary jazz, North Indian, blues and classical styles.
In 2016, at age 13, Anushka Naiknaware was the youngest winner of the Google Science Fair, with her invention of a clever new bandage that tells caregivers when it needs to be changed.
Mwende "FreeQuency" Katwiwa is a storyteller, a truth-teller, a builder and breaker trying to figure out what it means to be human in a world that removes so much of our humanity in order to survive.
Asali DeVan Ecclesiastes imagines equitable solutions to community and societal problems and works with her community to implement those solutions.
G.T. Bynum is using data-driven outcomes and trackable goals to break down historic lines of division.
Giulia Enders is working to reveal how our gut is at the core of who we are.
Luvvie Ajayi Jones is a two-time New York Times bestselling author, podcast host and sought-after speaker who thrives at the intersection of humor, media and justice.
Inés Hercovich is a pioneer in the study of sexual violence against women.
Paul Hessburg studies very large forest landscapes and what makes them tick.
Leah Chase spent seven decades serving her signature gumbo and hospitality to everyone from Martin Luther King Jr. to James Baldwin to Barack Obama.

Martina Flor combines her talents as designer and illustrator in the drawing of letters. Through her work as an artist and teacher, she has helped establish letter design in the European design scene.
Agnes Binagwaho helped rebuild the Rwandan health care system and continues to fight for positive change in global health.
Anielle Reid is an American singer-songwriter and banjoist.
Danielle Wood designs satellites and space technology applications that contribute to sustainable development.
A leading expert on sustainable materials, Andrew Dent has played an important part in creating a new generation of more sustainable products.

Drew Philp is the author of "A $500 House in Detroit: Rebuilding an Abandoned Home and an American City," a memoir of rebuilding a former abandoned home while finding his place in his city, country, race and generation.

As an IBM Distinguished Designer, Adam Cutler has spent the last 18 months exploring the intersection of artificial intelligence and human nature. His team is studying the fundamentals of how human relationships form and develop, with an eye on applying these same concepts to the growing number of relationships between humans and machines.

David is founder and CEO of The Plastic Bank, the world’s only organization to monetize plastic waste and provide an opportunity for the world's disadvantaged to collect and trade plastic waste as a currency.

Natalie obtained her postgraduate degree in structural biology and now focuses her_x000D_
research in the world of AI and technology. In her studies, she investigated the structure and function of a protein important in cancer. She has brought her biological background to IBM Research, where she and her team develop innovative machine learning applications to solve the top challenges in healthcare. Natalie is passionate about translating the work she does to improve the lives of people all around the world.

Phil Tetlow is an Executive IT Architect and a valued member of the Academy of Technology’s Leadership team, who is contributing in ways that often assist, improve and stimulate leading-edge ideas. Phil joined IBM Software Group, in 2013, to help lead the data and analytics team in the UK, advising IBM’s European execs on data strategy and technology trends. He’s won a major international award for his first book, “The Web’s Awake”, gained the first PhD in Web Science and has been credited as being one of the field’s pioneers. Data in general and Ultra Large-Scale Systems are his thing.

Rana is a Syrian American advocate for refugees and civilians in conflict, and the solution owner of IBM’s Refugee & Migration Predictive Analytics Solution -- a first-of-a-kind solution, leveraging machine learning and cognitive computing to enable Government agencies and humanitarian aid organizations to better manage refugee and migration crises._x000D_
She’s been published in the Wall Street Journal, WIRED magazine, and her work has_x000D_
been cited by Yale University and the Foreign Policy Initiative.
IBM's Raphael Arar creates art and designs experiences that examine the complexities of our increasingly technocentric lives.

Robin is the director and producer of cause‐based documentary films at Finish Line Features, Inc. and Unleashed Productions, Inc. As a business woman, long time professional photographer and social entrepreneur, Robin brings her leadership skills, creative eye and passion to her documentary film projects. Her artistic vision and experience in the business world afford her a unique perspective on what it takes to motivate an audience. Her most recent award‐winning film, CODE: Debugging the Gender Gap, premiered at Tribeca Film Festival 2015, and has caught the eye of the international tech industry and of policy makers and educators in Washington, DC and abroad. Robin is currently directing and producing bias, a documentary about unconscious bias and how it affects our lives socially and in the workplace.
A theoretical physicist by training, IBM's Simone Bianco believes that the 21st century will be the century when the synergy between AI and biology will be fully realized.

Tapiwa Chiwewe, PhD, manages the advanced and applied artificial intelligence group at IBM Research – Africa, which uses artificial intelligence to develop solutions for some of Africa's grand challenges whilst making scientific advances.
Eric Berridge is an entrepreneurial humanist who believes our society is overly obsessed with STEM.

Lisa Feldman Barrett, PhD is a University Distinguished Professor of Psychology at Northeastern University, with positions in psychiatry and radiology at Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School.

Eleftheria Pissadaiki, PhD, has a long-term interest in brain diseases, neurodegeneration and particularly in the etiopathology of Parkinson’s disease. In joining the high impact research and human studies team at IBM, Eleftheria contributes her neuroscientist research on projects related to human care, Parkinson’s disease and the detection of motor signatures that foreshadow daily fluctuations of the disease’s symptoms.

Bruno is a Distinguished Researcher and a member of the US National Academy of Engineering. He has worked to make computers more compact, efficient and powerful using bionic or bioinspired concepts bringing forth major positive impacts on the information and energy industries. He is a leading cross-disciplinary innovator both at the level of scientific breakthroughs as well as at an applied technological level. He is currently leading an effort that brings sensing, computing, and artificial or augmented intelligence much closer to humans thereby making it much more valuable and useful.

Tanmay, began coding at the age of five and is among the youngest cognitive and cloud computing developers, building applications engineered to augment human capabilities via Deep Learning. Now 14, his passion for learning and sharing about numerous topics such as Cognitive & AI, Tanmay is transforming the way technology is used to overcome obstacles in various fields; mainly, healthcare and security. This is seen through his work towards healthcare technology, which aims at extending the capabilities of the disabled, and saving lives through AI and cognitive systems.

Recently named one of Oprah’s SuperSoul 100 thought leaders, IN-Q groundbreaking performances include selling out the largest one-man poetry show in Los Angeles history, being the first spoken word artist to perform with Cirque Du Soleil, and being featured on HBO's Def Poetry Jam. As a songwriter, IN-Q’s hit single “Love You Like a Love Song” by Selena Gomez went multi-platinum, winning him a BMI award. He has also written with renowned artists including Aloe Blacc, and Miley Cyrus. IN-Q writes to entertain, inspire, and challenge his audiences to look deeper into the human experience and ask questions about themselves, their environment and the world at large.

Francisco Fernandez has been the bucking force behind his unstoppable outlaw cowboy band for the last ten years. The Ferocious Few's punkabilly roadhouse rock & roll has commanded attention everywhere they play, charging upwards from the streets of San Francisco to headlining SF's The Great American Music Hall and opening for Cyndi Lauper on her Memphis Blues tour as well as festivals such as Coachella and Lightning in a Bottle.

As the Senior Specialist for Creativity and Scenarios, Alan Iny has trained thousands of executives and BCG consultants on how to think creatively. A member of the firm’s strategy leadership team, he has vast experience in advising companies worldwide in innovation, scenarios, transformation, organization design and change management across industries. In 2013, Iny launched “Thinking in New Boxes: A New Paradigm for Business Creativity,” written with Luc de Brabandere and published by Random House.

James Curleigh is the President of the Levi’s brand, where he manages the brand’s strategic direction and execution. Prior to Levi Strauss & Co., James served as the President and CEO of Keen Footwear, Inc. and was president and CEO of Salomon Sports North America. He also established and led the TaylorMade-Adidas golf division in Europe and held various leadership positions in the London office of M&M Mars.

Joe Davis is BCG's Chairman of North America and a member of the firm's Executive Committee. In his role, he oversees BCG’s operations in the United States, Canada and Mexico. He was recognized as one of Consulting magazine’s Top 25 Consultants in 2011 for excellence in the public sector.

Leslie Perlow is the Konsuke Matsushita Professor of Leadership at the Harvard Business School and author of the book, “Sleeping With Your Smartphone.” She is an ethnographer who studies what happens when organizations experience tremendous change in the workplace -- such as globalization, 24/7 technology and hyper-efficiency -- but fail to consider their implications on how people work.

Since joining BCG in 1980, Michael Silverstein has served in a number of leadership roles, most recently as leader of BCG’s client service initiative and as a member of the firm’s Executive Committee. Michael specializes in helping large multinationals transform their companies through superior consumer insight, accelerated organic growth and M&A. He is the author and co-author of “Trading Up,” “Treasure Hunt,” “Women Want More” and “The $10 Trillion Prize” on the newly affluent class in China and India.

Vishal Sikka is a member of the Executive Board of SAP AG and the Global Managing Board, leading all SAP product development and innovation. He has global responsibility for research and academic and government relations. Sikka has led the development and delivery of SAP’s breakthrough in-memory platform, SAP HANA. He is also the author of “Timeless Software,” which explores the renewal of products without disruption to customer environments.
TED Resident tobacco brown is a social artist working at the public intersection of environmental art and restorative justice.
TED Resident Michael Rain communicates ideas through written and visual stories.

Whether speaking to barbers about early literacy, entertaining strangers at comedy clubs, or reading to kindergarteners at a local school, TED Resident Alvin Irby endeavors to make learning relevant and engaging.
TED Resident Jason Shen uses data and technology to help leaders identify talent.

Bob Stein has long been in the vanguard: immersed in radical politics as a young man, he grew into one of the founding fathers of new media. He’s wondering what sorts of new rituals and traditions might emerge as society expands to include increasing numbers of people in their eighties and nineties.
Malika Whitley is an arts curator and activist in Atlanta, Georgia.
Yvette Alberdingk Thijm helps activists use video and technology to protect and defend human rights.

Alexis Charpentier (aka Lexis from Music Is My Sanctuary) believes record collectors, music curators and DJs serve a crucial role as cultural preservationists and alternative voices to mainstream music platforms.
Marily Oppezzo studies how the movement of the body can affect the movement of the mind.
Former United States Congressman Bob Inglis promotes free enterprise action on climate change.

speaker_name: Nina Dølvik Brochmann and Ellen Støkken Dahl
speaker_description: Nina Dølvik Brochmann, M.D. wants to empower women through good sexual education.
Nilay Kulkarni is the co-founder and chief technical officer of Ashioto Analytics, a real-time crowd flow analysis platform.
Tamekia MizLadi Smith wants to start new conversations around involving non-clinical staff in healthcare.

Aaswath Raman is a scientist passionate about harnessing new sources of energy, mitigating climate change and more intelligently understanding the world around us -- by better manipulating light and heat using nanoscale materials.

Alex Honnold is a professional rock climber whose audacious free-solo ascents of_x000D_
America's biggest cliffs have made him one of the world's most recognized climbers.
Angel Hsu is a professor and data geek who applies data-driven methods to solve challenging environmental issues.
César Hidalgo studies how teams, cities and nations learn.
Charles C. Mann calls himself "a fella who tries to find out interesting things and tell others about them."
With charm and incisive wit, Christoph Niemann sketches the moments of our shared experience.
Dan Gibson leads a new breed of bioengineers, called genome writers, who use DNA to design and build new products powering the next industrial revolution.
The creator of emotional, immersive games like "Heavy Rain," "BEYOND: Two Souls" and "Detroit: Become Human," David Cage uses games to push the boundaries of storytelling.
Dylan Marron takes complicated social issues and finds accessible ways to talk about them through interviews, short-form videos and satire.
Emily Nagoski teaches women to live with confidence and joy inside their bodies.
Gary Liu is CEO of the South China Morning Post, a leading news media company that has reported on China and Asia for more than a century.
Giada Gerboni works in surgical robotics, supporting surgeons with new flexible robotic devices in order to make once impossible operations a reality.

Ian Firth designs bridges all around the world; some are very long and cross over wide rivers or sea channels, and some are really short and in the middle of towns and cities, but "all of them are unique and special in their own way."
Jaron Lanier is a scientist, musician and writer best known for his work in virtual reality and his advocacy of humanism and sustainable economics in a digital context.
When Jason B. Rosenthal's wife died, he says: "as clichéd as it sounds, I started working on living each day as it comes, to get through the complexities of life."
Jennifer Wilcox works on ways to test and measure methods of trace metal and carbon capture, to mitigate the effects of fossil fuels on our planet.
Kai-Fu Lee has spent more than three decades at the cutting edge of artificial intelligence research, development and investment both in the US and China.
Karen J. Meech is an astronomer who investigates how habitable worlds form and explores the bigger picture of whether there is life elsewhere.
Kate Raworth is passionate about making economics fit for the 21st century.
Kirsty Duncan works for all Canadians to nurture science in Canada and encourages people of all ages to have inquisitive minds.
Max Tegmark is driven by curiosity, both about how our universe works and about how we can use the science and technology we discover to help humanity flourish rather than flounder.

Penny Chisholm studies an extremely tiny microorganism that plays an enormous role in ocean ecosystems. Discovered only three decades ago, it has defined her career and inspired her to think differently about life on Earth.
Pierre Barreau is an entrepreneur, computer scientist, composer and director who loves to create impactful things.
Renzo Piano is a builder of shelters for human beings. And communities.
Simone Giertz runs a YouTube channel about robotics.
Stephen Webb is a science fiction fan who's passionately interested in what the future might hold for our species.
Vishaan Chakrabarti believes that cities -- if they are designed to be sustainable, equitable and joyous -- are the best hope for humanity.
As the head of a student group called Uncomfortable Learning, Zachary R. Wood made a point of engaging in conversation with people he disagreed with.
Will MacAskill is a cofounder of the effective altruism movement, a philosophy that tries to answer the question: How can we do as much good as possible?
Simona Francese is a chemist by training who is passionate about forensics.
At Sightsavers, an international NGO, Caroline Harper leads efforts to eliminate avoidable blindness around the world and fight for equal rights.
Rodin Lyasoff makes improbable objects fly.
Dustin Schroeder develops and uses geophysical radar to study Antarctica, Greenland and the icy moons of Jupiter.
Elizabeth Streb is an extreme action specialist who flies, crash-lands and invents hardware to get higher, faster, sooner, harder.
Frances Frei is a professor of technology and operations management at the Harvard Business School.
Heidi M. Sosik is an ocean scientist who uses tools like lasers and robotic cameras to figure out how tiny organisms in the ocean affect our whole planet.
Working across technologies and disciplines, James Bridle examines technology, knowledge and the end of the future.
Kashmir Hill writes about privacy and technology.
